Breaking it allowed them inside but their delayed arrival, rather than soothe the fallen men, triggers their ire: couldn't they have come faster? Don't they see their freezing limbs? Don't they know the fright they caused?

<b>The groggy men are cooperating at last.</b> A just dosage of tranquillisers tones down their panic while keeping them conscious, and the wounded let themselves be guided out of the crevasse and back to the ship. When the drugs and the cold wear out, they realise how oblivious they were to the real extent of their injuries.

<b>Their artificial calm lasts eternally.</b> The dosage of tranquillisers is on the nose and doesn't even take into account the weakened state of the patients. Their panic calms down at an alarming speed, then fainting follows, then a sleep so deep it takes away their breath and their heartbeat. At least they died peacefully.

<b>They calm down and can finally be rescued.</b> Your sailors are respectful of the wounded's pain and sympathise with them, soothing their angst with empathy and welcomed admiration. The injured swallow their insults and try to live to their companions' expectations, holding their whimpers until they are back on the ship. Their wounds are a nasty sight but their pride is beaming.

<b>Their panic soars and push them to their death.</b> Your sailors try to motivate the wounded through accurate descriptions of their fate, pointing at their darkened limbs and prophesying their coming fall. The injured enter a state of pure terror, screaming continuously and unable to hear themselves, crawling away from the news bearers and deeper into the chasm, until the snow dampens their screams and the sound of their final fall.

<b>The glacier forbids your sailors from finding their way through it.</b> The twisting paths of the frozen structure are too much for the crew, who already encountered trouble following the main marked glacier route. They are forced to abandon their quest and must go back to the broken mantle and its crevasse. The cold steadily bites and weakens them, and they soon take the same purple tint as the men they are trying to save.

<b>Your sailors' best effort cannot compensate the loss of time.</b> The crew's physical ability is of excellent nature, but the cold suffers no exception when it comes to eating flesh. The wounded are pulled up and the fangs of ice tear their feet and legs away, keeping these trophies as fees for the men's freedom. They are brought back to the ship but can never truly take part in the expedition again.

<b>A terrible initiative.</b> Several sailors slip into the crevasse, pushing and pulling the wounded up the frozen walls at the cost of what little energy they have. Their panting draws lines of mist around them and the faint clouds of breath thicken and thicken and suddenly evaporate. There is no more saving to be done for the injured and their rescuers.

<b>Heartbreaking.</b> Could they have resolved this in any other way? Your sailors try to ignore the question while they point their guns at their companions, men too frozen now to realize what's about to happen. They die silently, and the absence of protest weighs heavier than any voiced reproach on the would-be rescuers.

<b>They had it coming.</b> This is not your crew's first encounter with the dangers of the wild, yet they persisted in being foolhardy and ignored the basic rules of mountain hiking. Let their fate be a lesson for the other idiots.

<b>This man is severely ill!</b> A group of sailors bang on the door to the doctor's cabin. They carry a feverish friend, who between two moments of altered sleep mutters about a burning radiance and closes his eyes to protect himself from the deck's half-light. The doctor's inspection could reveal more symptoms, but shouldn't the crazed patient be secluded instead?

<b>The symptoms speak for themselves.</b> The man's neck is stiff, his breathing distraught, his cheeks paralysed. As the doctor explains to the rest of the crew the details of meningitis, the lying patient suddenly trembles, taken by a seizure of such intensity that his whole body arches upwards, bent in a pyramidal pose of impossible tension. He screams out the name of your doctor before falling down, dead.

<b>There is no truth but the voice of science.</b> The accusation was the plea of a sick fool. Your doctor knows what ravages meningitis can do in the mind of its victims, and his collected account of symptoms convinces your crew of your doctor's innocence and acute knowledge. He is free to inspect all men onboard and identifies who else carries the symptoms: the sick are promptly isolated and disembarked at the next harbour. Your expedition is unscathed!

<b>The doctor's truth isn't convincing.</b> He fumbles through his explanations as his limited knowledge of the dead man's illness shows, and if the doctor did seem to correctly identify the ailment, he fails to justify the impressive death the crew just witnessed. Doubts linger as the expedition goes on, and the doctor spends the rest of trip isolated in a quarantine of defiance and distrust.

<b>Heavenly truths hide in the last wishes of a man.</b> The doctor is pressed for answers and asked to swear his innocence before the Lord: a feat too great and a lie to heavy for him to bear. He confesses to having poisoned the sailor with mercury over a dispute of faith against facts - ironically, the doctor's own fear of the Light made him confess his sins. He is hanged and your crew finds relief in the punishment of the murderer.

<b>Isn't this judgement too hasty?</b> The doctor is immediately accused of having murdered the sick sailor, but he isn't enough of a believer to confess before the cross. He is nevertheless hanged for his supposed crimes. Relief tints the mood of your crew, but many know the punishment was hasty and unjust.

<b>Your doctor is at a loss.</b> Fear of the light sounds like an ailment belonging to the realm of the Lord, and the man of science is too blinded by his fright to notice the change in his patient. In a fit of unforeseen anger, the sick man leaps on his healer and attempts to claw his eyes out before being restrained by the surrounding sailors. What madness is this?

<b>Rabies, no doubt - confine him!</b> The man's unnatural fury keeps growing under the observations of the doctor, who finally discerns familiar patterns in his patient's behaviour. The massive salivation and rejection of any form of drink leave little room for doubt: he has rabies. The sailors confine him into the hold without remorse, and wait for the illness to steal his life.

<b>The symptoms culminate in death.</b> The roped patient wriggles, drooling and screeching and screaming for the lights to be gone, until a seizure of astonishing magnitude takes him and leaves his cadaver frozen in an impossible position. The doctor realizes, too late, that he might have been facing a case of rabies. Around him the crew grows restless: what if this failure of a scientist was still wrong?

<b>The flesh carries proof.</b> In the thigh of the dead man, your doctor discerns burn marks unlike any other, appended over a festering wound. This is the work of a priest, who applied a heated key of Saint Hubert over the bite of a rabid dog - in the hope, visibly misplaced, that the Saint would cure the ailment. The sailor had known of his fate but chose to endanger his companions regardless. He deserved death.

<b>Your crew has had enough of the doctor's incapability.</b> The man of science probes the body, tearing its clothes to reveal bruised skin and vulnerable flesh - a sight which convinces the sailors that they have seen the boundaries of his skill. The doctor is seized and roped alongside the cadaver he was desecrating, and left to ponder over his calling in the depths of the hull. At the next harbour, your crew realises that the doctor's wrinkled mass will never do harm nor good again.

<b>Undisputable evidence points to a grim story.</b> The inspection of the dead man's belongings lands no result, but your sailors know better than to consider this failure as final. They extend their search to the sleeping quarters, and within the loose planks of an amateurish repair, they find their proof: a key of Saint Hubert, vital artefact for any believer suspecting the menace of rabies. The sailor knew of his ailment and chose to hide it. This truth pains your crew but the closure brings relief.

<b>No proof, no trust.</b> Your sailors are not good hounds, especially under pressure, and they find no proof pointing to the nature of the dead man's illness. Suspicion rises as the doctor orders the immediate burial at sea of the cadaver. Long after the cloth-wrapped body was thrown into the sea, the cadaver of the dead man is found hidden in the hull. There is little doubt as to who was thrown overboard in its place.

<b>Your sailors will have nothing to do with this lunacy.</b> Sending the sick man to the depths of the hold is a cruel choice, but it lowers the risk of any otherworldly contamination. His howls bedevil the ship until his voice becomes whisper, then silence. His body is buried at sea in a hurried parody of ceremony whereas the sailors avoid discussing his unknown illness.

<b>The sick die alone.</b> Afraid of the man's state and the contagion he could potentially spread, your sailors lock him up in an emptied cabin. He opposes no resistance and during the following days, his presence is reduced to sporadic whimpers and the occasional monologue. When the voice finally dies out, the sailors carefully wrap his body in cloth and bury him at sea, both relieved and sorry that they let him die a dog's death.

<b>A ship trapped in the floe!</b> While navigating the treacherous Northern seas, your expedition happens upon frozen waters, whose masses spread over the horizon and plant their roots deep below the surface. Their dominion imprisoned a ship much like yours. Skin parched, voice torn, eyes buried deep in their skulls, the stranded sailors sacrifice their last bits of strength to beg for help.

<b>Scurvy.</b> When inspecting the mouths of the stranded sailors, your doctor's fingers expertly go through their gums like if they were made of paper and the teeth below quit their lodging with a shake and a pull. The ill men admit to having already buried at sea two of their own. More will follow if they do not eat fresh food soon.

<b>Your loss will help their survival, no doubt.</b> The gifted supplies are enough for the strangers to hold out until rescue comes. Your crew promises to look for the nearest harbour and call for help there - a promise which they are likely to keep, forced that they will be to resupply in order to avoid their own starvation.

<b>There are not enough supplies for both your crew and theirs.</b> Your sailors stop rummaging through their cargo and must deny the stranded men their hope of renewed supplies. The poor souls are too weak to vent their anger, but their empty looks and cursing whispers follow your crew long after the ghost ship has been swallowed by the horizon.

<b>The icy domain gives a profuse bounty.</b> Your fishermen forsake the idea of exploring the floe, knowing that the local game hides underwater. They catch enough seals to feed the whole crew and the feast, if it does not miraculously heal the sick, seems to replenish their spirit. They encourage your crew to use cannons to break the ice encasing their ship - despite the risk of damaging their hull.

<b>The ship is freed!</b> Your artillery men take hold of the stranded ship's cannons, ordering the crew in their handling of the frozen artillery and coordinating them with your own firepower. The combined shots from both vessels trace the contours of the ice, breaking it with successive volleys until the floe parts and lets go under the united cheer of both crews. One of the sailors who helped shooting, taken with your crew's kindness and its brilliant skills, even offers to join it.

<b>Your shots break the ice along with their hull.</b> Shooting a cannonball through the exact thickness of the ice without going any further requires a degree of control that your artillery man doesn't have. The blast pierces through the floe with a resounding crack, but the splinters projected by the impact are both ice and wood. The stranded sailors are thankful for your help and the water cushioned most of your cannonball's power, but your crew still feels guilt at seeing their ship hobble away.

<b>Your crew promises to send help.</b> They leave the stranded men after telling them of steam-powered icebreakers and expeditions versed in the art of rescuing people such as them, and the tales seem to satisfy their angst. Your sailors hope that the next harbour will indeed provide such saviours.

<b>The hunters can't find enough food.</b> Your sailors manage to track, find and trap seals but the bounty is not enough to feed a whole crew of ailing men. It might be enough for them to hold out until the arrival of a rescue mission - if there were less of them, or if they followed a strict rationing discipline.

<b>They are desperate for help and accept your proposal.</b> Your diplomat pressures the strangers more than she reassures them, and her pragmatic approach to the problem manages to convince them. About a third of the sick embark on your ship whereas the remaining sailors huddle together to share the meagre food that was hunted for them. Going back and forth between the closest harbour and the trapped ship drains your crew and your time, but the rescued men are indefinitely grateful.

<b>Your diplomat cannot convince them to commit self-sacrifice.</b> Rather than depicting the reasons behind your crew's decision, she bluntly announces the number of strangers allowed on board, and sparks an immediate frenzy. The skeletal men rise on trembling legs, their limbs pulled forward by the puppet strings of hunger, rushing into each other until most strings are cut. The culled crew climbs aboard your ship and their soulless presence plagues the rest of the expedition.

<b>The system is strict but allows them to hold their ground.</b> One of your officers and two of your biggest, most impressive sailors go down on the stranded ship to distribute food portions and teach the men about the merits and secrets of disciplined rationing. The crew nods their understanding, silent as your ship sails away. Hopefully they will follow your advice and most will still be alive when a rescue ship comes to their aid.

<b>Your frail discipline falls apart.</b> One of your officers and a handful of escorting sailors order the starved men to ration the meat lest they suffer from even more famine while your ship goes to look for help. Their lack of presence and conviction has no impact on the sailors, who throw themselves on the supplies and transform into beasts, frail animals who lack the strength to rip each other apart despite their will to do so. Your ship leaves in a hurry, leaving the fools to their madness.

<b>The floe is barren.</b> Unable to catch any game on the frozen ice and the surrounding hills of snow despite the numerous tracks sprinkling the area, your hunters come back empty-handed and ashamed. The stranded sailors appreciate the effort but their eyes grow duller still. They are still desperate for any kind of help.

<b>The unknown illness might attack your crew.</b> Your doctor cannot pierce the mystery of the strangers' ailment: their ghost-like bodies fascinate as much as they terrify. Too scared to properly inspect their cadaverous skin, he hurriedly affirms that any sort of prolonged contact with them would put your own sailors in danger. Your ship whisks your crew away from the imaginary threat, leaving the strangers to die.

<b>A job carried with few hitches.</b> Making sure that they do not damage the ship itself, your sailors fire cannonball after cannonball, taking the time to appraise an readjust their aim with each new shot. The ship's hull is grazed by the first shots and soon the floe parts before the vessel, the ice blocks gliding against each other with menacing cracks. The trapped crew profusely thanks yours! Your sailors revel in their saviour act, trying to ignore the emaciated faces and feeble voices.

<b>Reckless failure.</b> Your sailors have no notion of subtlety and even less understanding of their own firepower: the very first cannonball crashes into the ice and flies through the water and into the trapped hull below. Frozen foam explodes and stains the floe with streaks of grey which all point at the gaping hole in the wooden frame. The stranded crew trembles back and forth to secure the leak and refuses any more help.

<b>The best that could have been done.</b> The strangers accept your sailors' offer with reluctance, eyeing the leakage they caused more than the food they offer. The compensation is enough to put your own crew in the need of rationing but it does not absolve its mistakes. Your ship leaves with promises to call for help at the next harbour, eager to leave the judging stares.

<b>The situation gets as bad as it could.</b> Enraged by your retraction, the stranded crew flings resounding insults at your crew, then splinters from the broken hull, then the crates they had prepared to store your offering, then actual men. Fuelled by their ire and moving despite their cadaverous state, the assailants fire at will, oblivious to the retort of your crew. When the wraiths finally give in to death, your officers start to count the bodies.

<b>Your crew leaves the stranded men to fend for themselves.</b> There's no mistaking the leak for a negligible issue: if the skeletal state of the sailors is any indication, they will never have the strength to fix their ship. Allowing them to keep their pride might have been the granting of a last wish.

<b>The strangers are left to their grim fate.</b> One of your sailors crystallises your crew's fears by signing himself as the trapped ship disappears in the distance. The wraiths onboard were so close to death they had already taken its guise.

<b>A local girl is dead, of smallpox;</b> a disease your expedition has without doubt brought to these shores. As her mother weeps over her limp and hive-speckled body, it seems inevitable that the contagion will take more lives. "Perhaps we can vaccinate?" says the Captain, "at the very least we can recommend precautions to prevent the disease spreading."

<b>Such a well-prepared vaccination programme will cost...</b> Your expert doctor adapts an effective preparation in the circumstances, using up a fair quantity of the ship's medical supplies in the process. One of the officers wonders if you shouldn't receive something back for all this charity...

<b>The locals see no other choice but to accept</b>— anything to prevent the epidemic your doctors have so gravely forecast. Your crew readily receive their offerings without stopping to consider the dubious ethics of such an exchange. After all, it was they who brought the sickness to this place!

<b>You recruit an aspiring doctor!</b> With little debate, the locals agree to receive the vaccinations against smallpox, probably saving their lives in the process. It is perhaps a side-effect of the openness and apparent selflessness with which your own medics go about the task, that a local doctor is inspired to join your expedition.

<b>The doctor falls sick.</b> You can only assume the attempted vaccine has failed the locals also, because two weeks into the onward journey, its creator is in the grip of smallpox. Once the disease sets in there is no cure, unless you choose to trust the poor doctor's survival to God.

<b>A brave few serve as guardian angels,</b> praying, washing, comforting the doctor. The acrid smell of the pustules, so particular to smallpox, is soon masked by haloes of incense. After several weeks the doctor's fever goes down and the rashes become less pronounced. While no miracle— the skin will forever bear the scars— it does mean the doctor's survival.

<b>Smallpox spreads with a missionary zeal.</b> Following the priest's foolish suggestion that the crew all visit the doctor to offer their prayers, it is hardly a surprise when a spate of new cases are reported. Three weeks after the doctor dies, others are just beginning to experience the first agonising symptoms. Had your crew heartlessly abandoned the doctor, it would surely have been the better option.

<b>With regret, the doctor must be marooned.</b> Men in gloves carry a stretcher up the beach beyond the tideline to a place in the shade where it seems likely the doctor will live out a few more days. "Fresh air might revive you," says one optimistically, but already the doctor has no strength to reply.

<b>The instructions are followed to the letter.</b> The local people have never come into contact with smallpox before, but agree to adopt your measures against it. Your crew need reminding too; mouths covered when coughing, the avoidance of skin contact, and the frequent washing of hands in alcoholic solution. It is chastening that your mere presence has caused the death of that poor girl, but after two weeks without further cases, it is certainly a relief it does not appear to have spread.

<b>Your people find it impossible to get the message across.</b> The locals go about their business as usual, disregarding the strictures you have tried to put in place. Sensing the coming epidemic, and as fears for the health of your own crew mount, it may be time just to leave...

<b>Saved by a cow with cowpox.</b> Your doctors remember that the "vacca" of vaccination means cow, and extract cowpox from the pustuled udders of a local beast. Everyone receives the injection, which due to the lack of appropriate facilities the doctor is unable to purify. Fortunately this only results in a number of outbreaks of other, much less destructive infections.

<b>Things take a severe turn for the worse...</b> Your doctors have little idea what they are doing, and their extraordinary decision to use a sample from the pustules on the poor dead girl to create their vaccine only accelerates the spread. In desperation, those still in health agree to board the expedition ship and escape while they still can.

<b>Smallpox has wiped out entire civilisations.</b> That is the pervading anxiety as the expedition prepares for hasty departure. The locals seem unaware of the danger, perhaps thinking the death of the young girl an isolated case. Before leaving, one of your scribes grimly documents the customs and traditions of these peoples in case it should have to serve as the sole record of their having existed.

<b>The blue flowers have put the members of your expedition into a frightening delirium.</b> Among the tranquil villages of this delta, your crew had seen the water plants— baskets 'laden with flower and fruit,' everywhere, and been curious to try them. "You see it does them no harm," the Captain had said encouragingly, as they made friends of some locals upon the riverbank one sleepy afternoon. But not long into the delicious feast of flowers, your expedition party are experiencing wild hallucinations!

<b>The doctor chuckles.</b> "Here," he says, dosing each stricken soul from his medicine bag, "that should ease things." Soon everyone is sound asleep, and they waken the following day feeling refreshed. Unaware you have cheated, the Flower-eaters are impressed! No-one normally handles their first encounter with the flower so well. <b>Taking it as a sign, they offer you something equally precious.</b>

<b>The worried doctor issues an emetic,</b> "Throw it up, it is poison!" he says. Afterwards the crew feel extremely weak, but the effect of the drug does indeed begin to fade. "We just didn't have the guts for it," a sailor wipes his mouth. You have shown a weakness of constitution. All around, the Flower-eaters are share jokes at the crew's expense. <b>You leave humiliated.</b>

<b>"I have just the tonic!"  your wild-eyed doctor quavers,</b> pulling a bottle of Vin Mariani from his satchel. However, the mix of wine and coca leaves only serves to heighten the delirium. Some awaken from incoherence, others don't. The Flower-eaters are clearly puzzled, and offer their condolences, for no concoction so ill-advised or unfortunate, has ever been seen before or since.

<b>You are somehow able to communicate that you are suffering.</b> Many of the Flower-eaters are seeing visions themselves— the effect they expect by consuming the plant. The locals interrupt their own lucid dreaming to help your expedition through it, realising your lack of experience in such rites of passage. The next day, your cosmic travellers feel relieved to return to the more familiar rocking of their ship.
<b>Your men become aggressive.</b> Unable to communicate, they resort to grabbing the locals. "Drugged!" one cries, "what have you done to us?!" There is every danger this is about to turn nasty.

<b>The behaviour of your expedition is shameful.</b> One of the Flower-eaters is shoved to the ground in front of her children. When several others pile into the scrum, one of your crew, who shall go unnamed, decides to set fire to a watermill in protest. This doesn't help anyone still having hallucinations. The next morning when they awake, everyone claims not to remember anything.

<b>They battle bravely against their shadows!</b> Heeding the officer's commands to resist, each of your veterans summons their inner strength to endure the sway of the little blue flower, drenched with sweat and thrusting their hands into the empty air. Eventually the horrors give way to narcosis, and a deep sleep lasting several days. This land of water lilies will take valuable time from your odyssey.

<b>Nightmares reveal truths.</b> The paranoia of their hallucinations centres on each other— a history of indiscipline and bad blood, grudges never properly settled. The drug has liberated those who feel they have been wronged. At daybreak, one of your expedition lies drowned in the river. Officially, the influence of the sinister blue flower will likely be blamed, but others are already telling a different story.

<b>Your party open their minds to visions of the divine.</b> The horrors fade from view and in their place come forest creatures, nymphs and dryads. Grand cities swirling as if formed of cloud,  and golden ships voyaging up to the moon.<br/>When the visions disappear, the crew realise they have experienced something extraordinary, and relate what they have seen to their hosts. <b>The Flower-eaters offer a token of their appreciation</b> for a shared spiritual experience.

<b>Ahh...the intemperance of addiction.</b> Although they soon grow accustomed to the devilish hallucinations, your men now develop a profane appetite for the pleasures of the flower — slumber's holy balm. Procrastination, and apathy towards the supposedly 'materialistic objectives' of the expedition are the products of these indulgences. When finally dragged away from the sleepy waters, <b>the crew weep bitterly, and swear to be idle</b> for the remainder of their commission.

<b>Vampirical injuries!?</b> The path through the forest was barely visible beneath the lush vegetation. It isn't until they emerge from the pleasant shade of the trees that sunlight falls upon the crew, swelling up the skin of a few crew members with red rashes and throbbing blisters. Surely there must be a scientific explanation to their sudden photophobia...

<b>The cold water soothes the burning almost immediately. </b> They all enjoy a little break away from sunlight and gently wash the rashes off with soap in a forest pool of fresh water. The blisters are gone after a few hours and the group is ready to continue.

<b>Looks like your doctor did his homework!</b> "I read about something like this during my research of the hazards we could encounter in this region, they must have brushed against a giant hogweed!" The treatment is simple: enjoy a little break away from sunlight and gently wash their skin with clear cold water. The blisters are gone after a few hours and the group is ready to continue.

<b>The doctor dismisses the throbbing blisters as simple mosquito bites. </b> "Just try not to scratch them. If you can't help yourselves, rub them gently, that's all." But a few hours later, the vesicles have already extended throughout their entire body. They collapse, unable to take a step further, whimpering with unbearable pain.

<b>This time, the doctor takes the symptoms seriously.</b> "It looks like a chemical irritation. I wonder..." The doctor rummages through the nearby flora and in time he finds it: a tall stem crowned by an umbrella of small white flowers. "A giant hogweed! Of course, its sap causes phototoxicity." Fortunately, the treatment is simple: a cold bath and a long break in the shade. Once they're clean, the doctor heals and bandages the lesions. But it comes many hours too late — his negligence will leave leathery red scars on the wretched few.

<b>"It must be a rare breed of smallpox!"</b> Your squeamish doctor doesn't even lean close enough to the pustules before squealing: "Stay away from them! These people are doomed, there is nothing we can do but avoid contagion!" Panic ensues and those untouched by the rashes stampede away. The aching bunch are irresponsibly abandoned and left behind.

<b>A miracle!</b> The priestess sinks the cursed crew members in a forest pool and blesses their foreheads with the symbol of the cross. "Exsúrgat Deus et dissipéntur inimíci ejus", she recites, and the men and women exhale a sigh of relief, as the burning fades away. Although they will have to live with the devil's taint on their skin for the rest of their days, each and every single one of them feels thankful and blessed.

<b>The ritual is a most unholy sight. </b> "Sunlight will purge your curse, bear the pain as evil oozes out of your body!" The cursed few writhe under the scorching sun, as their blisters slowly morph into aberrant lumps of fluid. Everyone's beliefs shake before the nauseating vision. By sundown, they can barely move. It takes days for the throbbing bags of liquid to pop and peel off, leaving the hosts with bright red festering wounds. Massive scars will forever remind them of how they were forsaken by the gods.

<b>"It must be a rare breed of smallpox!"</b> Your squeamish doctor doesn't even lean close enough to the pustules before squealing: "Stay away from them! These people are doomed, there is nothing we can do but avoid contagion!" Panic ensues and those untouched by the rashes stampede away. The aching bunch are irresponsibly abandoned and left behind.

<b>The most upsetting weeks of their lives ensue from the thoughtless decision. </b> The constant wailing of the aching bunch wrecks everyone's nerves. Their blisters become as unbearably painful as nauseating to behold — they continue to swell, covering up most of their bodies. It takes days for the throbbing bags of liquid to pop and peel off, leaving the hosts with bright red oozing wounds. Massive scars will forever remind them of their harrowing pain.

<b>The ominous black spikes that covered the tree's trunk were far from the only danger it posed to the crew.</b> As they were carefully circling around it, a loud bang was heard and a man was sent to the floor with a painful yell. One of the tree's fist-sized wooden fruits had exploded, sending surprisingly sharp splinters into the man's right flank. Moving him could be fatal, but the shade of a tree that drops grenades is not the safest place to perform a surgery.

<b>Your doctor's fingers move as a prestidigitator's. </b>He quickly feels the man's abdomen and locates every shard. Then he pulls them out methodically and stitches the patient up. The crew escapes the hazardous tree's vicinity within a few minutes only, just in time to elude two new explosions.

<b>Stress and inexperience slow your doctor down. </b> With trembling fingers, he slowly pulls a piece of wood out of the man's abdomen. But there are many left to go, and the menacing creaks above their head make the young doctor shudder even more violently. Before long, another pumpkin-shaped grenade blasts both patient and doctor with wooden shrapnel. The latter manages to cover most of it with his forearms, but the patient's now coughing up blood.

<b>Despite his wounds, adrenaline steadies the doctor's hand. </b> Aided by two members of the crew, he decides to perform a laparotomy and open the patient's abdomen up. It is a gruesome, painful procedure that curdles the blood of everyone present, but the shards are successfully removed. Once the surgery is finished, half the crew is covered in blood and viscera, but both men can be safely taken back to the ship for recovery.

<b>The surgery was doomed to fail. </b> The doctor attempts to pull out another shard, but his own wounds make him shake uncontrollably, and he punctures a major blood vessel. A nurse tries to stop the haemorrhage, but he is too late: the patient bleeds out by the murderous tree. The crew helps the sobbing doctor up and dolefully walk away from its blood-soaked roots.

<b>"I've witnessed more grenade injuries than I'd like to remember; this is no different". </b> A grizzly sailor comes forward and pushes the injured doctor aside. "We can't repair the damage, but we may be able to contain it long enough for him to get to a clinic." He ties a firm knot around the critical areas and tightly braces the wounded man with cloth and bandages to prevent any potential haemorrhages. It is not perfect, and the man's howls clearly state that it is in no way painless, but he survives long enough to be treated at the nearest village.

<b>If the crew were truly under enemy fire, they would all perish. </b> Not one voice is heard above the heated discussion. "Getting away from danger is the priority, just help him up!", "He'll bleed out!", "Just swathe him together and let's get out of here!". Unable to reach an agreement, and with the explosive fruit dangling above their heads, a grizzly sailor decides to take matters into his own hands — quite literally. "Better out than in!", he grunts, as he dips his bare fingers into the man's open wounds and pulls out the gory pieces before the horrified gaze of the doctor. But it's too late to stop him, there's a ripping sound, then a gurgle, and blood starts gushing out the man's mouth. Nothing can be done to stop the bleeding and the dreadful scene is over within a minute.

<b>An easy feat for your handy crew.</b> They get to work immediately, and — in the blink of an eye — two long branches, two coats and a symmetrical tangle of knots become a rock-solid stretcher. The wounded man is carefully removed from under the grenade-bearing canopy and carried back to the ship, where the surgeon is able to safely extract every piece of timber shrapnel.

<b>Stress only serves to highlight your crew's lack of skill.</b> Eager to get away from the lethal tree's canopy as fast as possible, they hastily tie two branches together and call it a stretcher. The precarious device barely holds the weight of the wounded man, and it collapses almost immediately. The man hits the floor with a thud, and his howl of pain forecasts the worst: a fragment has pierced his liver. The man writhes in a feverish agony for days before drawing his last breath.

<b>An officer has taken a bite out of a fragrant, but deadly fruit. </b> By the time your guide alerts the crew to "stay away from la manzanilla de la muerte", its sweet taste is rapidly followed by a peppery tingle, then an excruciating burn. Soon, the officer is frantically gasping for breath, his throat and tongue tripled in size.

<b>The crew's hypnotised by your doctor's precision.</b> Without wasting a single second, she lays the officer in the sand, commands two men to pin him down, feels her patient's Adam's apple and makes one steady incision. She then inserts the handle of the scalpel in and rotates it to open the new orifice up. The sudden suction sound as air rushes back into the officer's lungs triggers a communal sigh of relief. The whole crew can finally resume breathing.

<b>The crew stirs before the grisly scene.</b> The panicked doctor — who's clearly never witnessed such a procedure before — stabs the officer in the throat with her knife in an attempt to poke a hole for him breathe through. Instead, the patient's blood spurts out on her face. Her piercing shriek makes the whole crew shudder. The man falls to his knees and bleeds to death within seconds.

<b>Your diplomat's voice soothes everyone around him.</b> He firmly grasps the officer by the shoulders and helps him lie down on his side. He gently instructs the officer to picture a toy horse, rocking softly back and forth with his every breath. Now that the man is not panicking, a small stream of air finds its way through his swollen windpipe, but an urgent treatment is required to remove the toxins from his body before it causes more damage.

<b>Before receiving the command, your doctor was already preparing to treat the officer. </b>She had clean warm water ready to be pumped into and back out of her patient's stomach through a rubber tube she expertly passed through the tiny gap left on his swollen pharynx. The gastric lavage is successful and the officer's windpipe slowly clears out. It isn't until he's out of danger that the whole crew realises everyone had been holding their breath.

<b>'Negligent' falls short to describe your doctor.</b> In an attempt to purge the poisonous fruit from the man's stomach, she pours seawater down the poor officer's mouth. Not only does he howl with pain the second salt touches his inflamed throat, the seawater makes him heave and choke on his blocked airways. The officer convulses and gurgles for five very long minutes before he stops twitching altogether.

<b>You master crafter conducts every crew member as a perfectly synchronised orchestra.</b> "Just any charcoal won't do, it needs to burn at a very high temperature and we don't have much time!" An airtight clay oven is set up and smoking in the blink of an eye. Not an hour has passed before the powdered charred coconut shells are being fed to the agonising officer, cleansing his body from every toxin.

<b>Your crew's ineptitude proves fatal.</b> Even though the doctor insists that the charcoal must have been burnt at a very high temperature for it to absorb the poison from the body, all they can think of is setting up a bonfire and charring some driftwood. After making the officer snort the hastily pounded coals, he starts bleeding profusely out of his mouth and nose, choking and writhing in agony. There is nothing your crew can do for the man but put him out of the misery they aggravated.

<b>Each word that blurts out of your first mate's mouth makes the man fret more violently.</b> Each crew member watches, helpless and distraught, as the agonising officer's lips turn purple, then blue, while the first mate continues to screech at him to "just calm down and breathe in". The look of panic in the man's eyes pierces the souls of every man and woman present just before falling unconscious. Nothing can be done for him.

<b>"I do hope you've nothing to hide?"</b> smirks the Royal Inspector, as his soldiers help him aboard from the row boat. Sailors twitch. Your ship is certain to contravene her majesty's law, since it has encroached into demilitarised waters.

<b>"Very good"</b>, grimaces the Royal Inspector, scarcely concealing his displeasure at having to let you off the hook. His remonstrations with his soldiers as he wobbles aboard the row boat are a great source of amusement for the crew in days to come.

<b>The Inspector's lip wobbles.</b> "I beg you," he says, "I have a gift, if only you will spare us." Sure enough, the gift is brought aboard as promised. But it is only once the Inspector and his soldiers are gone, that it feels safe enough to inspect the new acquisition.

<b>The Inspector's face pales</b> as he eyes the tigerish crew. He bows, and takes a half-step backward - a signal for his soldiers to disembark with him. Once gone, the crew breathe a great sigh of relief, knowing it to have been a close shave.
<b>"This is far from over!"</b> the Inspector snarls as he evacuates his men to the row boat. Sure enough, back aboard the royal clipper, he is seen making preparations to attack.
<b>Slippery as an eel,</b> steady navigation keeps your ship on the windward side, just out of the Inspector's clutches. After a tense pursuit he is forced to give up, to the crew's great relief.

<b>Though the ungainly clipper is outmanoeuvered,</b> the expedition is now many miles off course, and your ship's exhausted navigators must summon all their remaining stamina to get things back on track.

<b>It's upsetting that the Inspector's clipper</b> is near out of sight, when a hopeful last shot finds its mark, crashing in the main deck of your ship, and killing a luckless sailor. Despite having escaped, the crew are rattled by such ill luck.

<b>Complete confusion among the navigators</b> makes your ship a sitting duck, and the Inspector's clipper gleefully riddles it with cannonfire. Many die or are wounded, and the ship is left in shreds.

<b>The last they expect is a quick counter.</b> Surprised and windless, they're an easy mark. Your cannons flog the Inspector's clipper without reply, and before long, it is bubbling to the depths. The relieved crew scout the flotsam for spoils.

<b>Though the royal clipper has it worse,</b> it also deals significant damage to your ship in the chaotic exchange. With casualties and repairs on both sides, the ships agree to part, so that they may lick their wounds.

<b>The speed and power of the royal clipper</b> is impossible to match despite best efforts. Your ship takes significant damage, and a young sailor is killed by shrapnel. Retreat is the only option. Mercifully the Inspector chooses not to make pursuit.

<b>The superior clipper chews through your ship</b> with its dread bank of cannons - the ruthless Inspector intent on bringing traitors to their knees. "We surrender!" the crew cry, but the plea falls on deaf ears. Once he has shredded the ship to bits, the smug Inspector turns his clipper about, and disappears into the distance.

<b>There is a commotion</b> and the Inspector's soldiers are already among the crew. Being exceptionally well-drilled, they quickly force the crew to drop their weapons. "Now," says the Inspector, "if you are quite finished, I'd like to continue my inspection of your vessel!"
<b>"Load these crates aboard the clipper!</b> What are you waiting for?" he huffs to his men. When they are done, he smirks and offers the merest of bows, before sailing away with the plunder.

<b>"You will remain here until they are dismantled..."</b> trills the Inspector, "...those perverse modifications to your sails contravening sovereign law of the sea." As the nit-picking Inspector leaves, it is clear an arduous refit is needed before your expedition will be allowed to continue.

<b>"I don't know what you were thinking,</b> bringing an armed ship into these peaceful waters," he says. "but I take great pleasure in imposing upon you. the longest possible route around." Once the Inspector has gone, the crew look to one another in dismay.

<b>A disastrous melee ensues,</b> in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector calls three captive sailors forward. "Hang these men," he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

<b>A disastrous melee ensues,</b> in which the crew do not acquit themselves well. Some are skewered, the rest disarmed. The Inspector picks out the captive specialist. "Hang this traitor," he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

<b>"Rather excellent company",</b> says the Inspector over a glass of port, "I've been dying for something to break the tedium of the sea." Surprising even his own soldiers, the Inspector demands a gift be brought over from the clipper to mark the occasion. Of course, when he finally leaves, the crew collapse about in relief.

<b>"Very well,"</b> says the Inspector, after being given the first mate's 'special tour' of nothing in particular. He silently surveys the vessel for a torturous moment, before declaring "it all seems above board." Of course, as soon as he and his soldiers have disembarked, the crew of your ship collapse about in grievous relief.
<b>"Save your breath, windbag,"</b> says the Inspector, with an air of a man accustomed to weaseling. "Show me the damn ship, or I shall become vexed!"

<b>"You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,"</b> the Inspector sneers, pointing to three unlucky sailors. "Hang them," he says, and they are promptly strung from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

<b>"You've talked yourself into very serious trouble,"</b> the Inspector sneers, and points at your specialist. "Hang this traitor," he says, and promptly strings them from a beam until dead. Your ship, he decrees, must leave sovereign waters and take the long way round.

<b>The crew faces the bloody customs of foreign lands.</b> After a night of feasting, the sailors believe that meeting the foreign prince and his sea-traveling court is the highlight of their trip. However, morning comes with news of a sudden death among the court, and your crew is immediately accused of murder. The prince demands a trial by combat and your men are left with little freedom but the choice of the challenge's nature.

<b>What could a lord do against a sea-forged champion?</b> The prince's warrior is nothing more than a scarecrow in shiny armor, and your own cotton-clad fighter scoffs at his tacky opponent. The walking wardrobe is tripped, grabbed, and thrown overboard in a single movement. As per foreign laws, your crew receives compensation and their name is cleared.

<b>No word is brutal enough to describe your opponent.</b> If his plate armor is scaled to match the man inside, then that man is a giant. The human mountain reaches to grab your fighter and crushes his skull like he would an apple. Word of your crew's feebleness and alleged crimes is sent for all cities to know and spread.

<b>Your gunslinger shoots faster than his own shadow.</b> His opponent drop to the ground before anyone can see or even understand that a gun has been fired, and only the banging sound and fuming barrel testify to the attack. The prince wonders how lucky your sharpshooter is, then reluctantly graces the crew and presents them with compensation for his offense.

<b>Speed is not in your gunslinger's vocabulary.</b> The prince's duelist, displaying the look of men who fill graves but never dig them, is the sharpest shooter your sailors have ever seen. Your best shot is dead before he even touches the handle of his gun. Judging his passing to be too low a price, the prince randomly selects men among your crew and has them hanged for good measure.

<b>The foreigners are drawn in by your officer's pace.</b> He inspects the body, noticing knife cuts of varying depths and bleeding. Through methodical questioning, the officer presses the foreigners and reveals the deception: each wound was made by a different hand, the victim was killed by all of them! The prince buys the sailors' silence and they leave wondering what could have motivated the curious murder.

<b>A mute would have pleaded better.</b> The officer engages in a battle of arguments with the prince's vizier, and each of his meager claims are met with factual evidence of their contrary. The prince cuts the exchange with exasperation and has the officer taken to be quartered till torn apart as a final judgement for the supposed crime. No scream ever matches the ones heard that day.

<b>These hoodlums are asking for it.</b> To each harbour its own ill-famed tavern, and this one is no exception. While your crew enjoys a beer at the counter, the tavern's door slams open, the bartender stiffens and the volume of conversations dwindles: the newcomers are regulars of the bad kind. One of the scruffy men elbows your doctor and gasps as the alcohol splashes on his unkempt clothes. He immediately grabs your sailor by the collar and demands an apology.

<b>Your crew crushes them.</b> The collar-grabbed doctor slaps away the hand of the hoodlum, seizes his sleeve and pulls him above his shoulder, sending him to crash into a table. With a roar, the other thugs pounce on your sailors who greet them with jabs to the chin and sternum, downing the attackers with no more than two hits per man - the seconds for the pleasure of good fighting form. The tavern applauds the action and the bartender offers a round to celebrate the deserved beating.

<b>The crew overestimated themselves.</b> As he calls for the other sailors to help, the doctor gets his head smashed into the counter. His crewmates scream for revenge and look like toddlers agitating their little arms to try and hit the big bad guys. The thugs are not in the mood to play along, and one of them stabs a bawling sailor in the liver to make them shut up. They slowly die as the thugs depart, leaving the tavern in a stupor.

<b>The language of alcohol is universal.</b> The thugs take you up on your offer and eye the sailors' purses as they pass the money around to pay for the beers. As the first round arrives, one of the hoodlums speaks up and announces that they will have a drinking contest with the crew. The idea is one-sided and weirdly different from their previous aggressive attitude.

<b>They call that catpiss strong?</b> There's no question regarding who wins the drinking contest: your crew is still standing and enjoying the beers long after the thugs have hit the ground, curled into whatever their stomach rejected. The pungent smell of vomit and cheap ale does not deter the sailors, who casually finish their steins, pay for them, and drag the hoodlums to the closest man of law.

<b>What kind of liquid fire do they make this with?</b> The crew is used to strong drinks and exotic ales, but the tavern's special mixture of bourbon, sugar and Ricard is way past what they can handle. The thugs are accustomed to this local horror and barely wobble while your sailors pass out one after the other. When they wake up, obviously, their purses are missing.

<b>War anaesthetics are remarkably useful against small-time thugs.</b> After a few rounds spent boasting their virile resistance to any kind of liquor, the crew notices the drop in attention of their opponents and their doctor seizes the opportunity, lacing the incoming mugs with just the right dosage of chloroform. The snoring hoodlums are delivered to the local authorities, who enjoy the unexpected present.

<b>The dosage doesn't put the thugs to sleep: it kills them.</b> The doctor sidles among the thugs, lacing their drinks and snickering in expectation. Soon the effects appear: the gang shows drowsiness, then nausea, loses control of their movements and tumbles against the counter, their faces taking on a waxy yellow color. The crew can do nothing as the hoodlums break into seizures and foam at the mouth. They win the drinking contest by default, murderers of their opponents.

<b>Bribing them with alcohol doesn't seem to work.</b> Your crew invites the men to sit and share a beer, on them, to try and bring the tension down. The thug doesn't let go of the doctor and points at the aligned liquors behind the bartender. A glass of all of these, he says, and a bottle of your best whatever. That's way more than they can drink and way more than your sailors can afford.

<b>The crew is humiliated.</b> They empty their purses trying to pay for the excessive demands of the thugs. Ale. Stew. Liquors. Meats. When sunrise pushes the hoodlums to leave the tavern, the sailors are stuck with cooking, dishwashing and dust-wiping until the bartender considers their debt paid.

<b>Your sailors apologize through gritted teeth.</b> Pleased by their groveling, the thugs do not pester them anymore, yet the heavy stares of the other clients push your crew to leave the tavern. Next time, they will show them. Next time.

<b>Sails frozen, food rotten, ship on the brink of breaking.</b> It's a blizzard! All notion of time and direction has long been lost: a never-ending tempest of snow surrounds the ship, blurring the limits between night and day, sky and sea. Stalactites have imprisoned your sails, binding them to the masts and making them creak under the unexpected weight. Your crew fears they might break, but should anyone venture outside while violent winds whip the upper deck?

<b>The ship can safely withstand the blizzard.</b> Several sailors of impressive builds climb your masts to unhook and detach the heavy sails, and despite the slippery wood and tightly frozen ropes, they manage to free the masts of the dangerous weight. The barren poles stand tall against the receding storm. Morning light soon pierces the clouds, a good omen to salute your crew's efforts and accompany their celebration.

<b>The task is far from easy.</b> Your sailors have good strength and are used to climb the masts, but they lack either luck or skill when it comes to speed. Before they can reach the foremast, the fore sail breaks out of its bounds and flaps wildly against the weakened mast while the other sails continue to foster stalactites of increasing length and weight. The foremast emits a shrilling sound of protest.

<b>The rogue sail is taken down!</b> Precise shots take out its ties without so much as scratching the foremast, and the sail is sent to disappear into the storm. The lack of the sail's furious whipping seems to be enough for the mast to hold its ground. When the blizzard recedes, your ship is lacking a sail but nothing more.

<b>Alas, your mast is not spared.</b> Your sailors shoot at the ties of the fore sail but the task is too meticulous for them: they shoot at the ropes, the poles, the mast itself. The raging sail is swallowed by the storm while the foremast collapses and crushes the starboard. In a final irony, the storm soon calms down and lets your crew calculate how their lack of meddling would have caused less damage.

<b>The stalactites are dealt with.</b> In a bold act of defiance towards logic and prudence, your artillery men fire the cannons to send precisely gauged vibrations through your ship. The foremast protests but resists while the pikes of ice parasitising its sails break and rain on the deck in a cacophony of tingling sounds. Your maimed ship has but to wait for the blizzard to run out of breath now.

<b>Reckless, and proportionately paid.</b>Gauging the difference between power which might break the stalactites only and power which might also break the mast is beyond the understanding of most humans, your artillery men included. The tremor of the cannons shakes the whole ship and provokes the crashing fall of its foremast. Ironically, the blizzard reacts by calming down and leaves the sailors to their broken ship.

<b>Resounding failure.</b> Your sailors clearly don't have the ability to climb the masts, in this storm or in clear weather - how could they even be allowed on a ship? As they bicker over their deficiency, the main mast beckons their attention: its base is entirely frozen and the wood screams against the invading cold.

<b>A straightforward if rough solution.</b> Planks and poles are erected around the masts and bound by ropes and chains in the hope that the swaying barricade will prevent the masts from breaking. Despite its movement, the construction is sturdy and actually accompanies the masts as they move in the wind, giving them a welcome support. When the blizzard leaves, your ship is plucked naked but its masts still stand.

<b>The trigger of catastrophy.</b> Your sailors tie planks and poles around the masts, pulling chains around them as tightly as they can, oblivious to the carpentry laws ruling over the movement of towering objects. The masts try to break free of the man-made prisons and jump out of them, crashing onto the deck one after the other. As if chased by the hysteria below, the blizzard flees and lets sunrays fall on the barren carcass of your ship.

<b>Somehow, it works.</b> Your sailors take the time to slowly distil seawater in order to avoid improper condensation. The salt is acquired faster than anticipated and spread over the base of the main mast, forcing the ice back to its liquid form. The blizzard keeps filling the sails until it goes out of breath and recedes, but the furious weather was enough to greatly maim the ship. There will be extensive repairs.

<b>There was no chance of success.</b> To gather salt, your sailors keep away from the wind and bury inside the deck to lit a fire under a pot of seawater. Their condenser is poorly handled and causes the water to fall back into the pot - causing them to believe the fire isn't burning hard enough. They fan the flames. Hell rises. The blizzard is fed gusts of murky smoke and spits it back out before receding, revealing the half-burnt carcass of your ship.

<b>Prudence and faith pay off.</b> Your sailors huddle together in the lower deck, resisting the temptation to go check the masts and their frozen sails. Time trickles away as the storm recedes, and when the blizzard is no more than a light drizzle, the sun emerges to illuminate your ship. It's perfectly unscathed and slowly drifts towards the coast, where a harbour is already in sight.

<b>Your sailors' feeble trust is not enough to fuel their patience.</b> The storm lingers and with each new gust of raging wind the main mast complains and moans, until distinct sounds of breaking wood resonate through the ship. That's enough waiting! Several sailors rush to the upper deck in the hope of strengthening or defrosting the mast.

<b>You have a hardy legion indeed.</b> They rush to the tarpaulins, and with commendable teamwork and physical strength in the challenging conditions, are able to pull them over the ship's most sensitive instruments and machinery. Heading below deck to relax, <b>the heroes wait out the storm in luxury</b> with buttered currant buns and hot tea.

<b>Their defence of the steamship is a little half-hearted.</b> Initially the men show willing, but the blizzard quickly wears them down, and they retreat inside claiming that their work is done. After the worst of it has passed, the officers survey the ship. Beneath a poorly affixed and feeble tarpaulin, the engine is found to have suffered damage, albeit fixable. <b>One has to wonder if they are cut out for these kinds of challenges.</b>

<b>Tragic youthful over-exuberance.</b> Your sailors drain a bottle of strong rum before going back out, perhaps believing machismo will keep them warm. They batten the hatches in the white flurry, stumbling, belching and laughing. The hilarity continues when one of the lads slips and loses his feet, that is until the steel rim of the funnel meets his head with a clomp. <b>He dies instantly.</b>

<b>The thrill-seeking diver relishes the task.</b> Covering themselves in bear fat and brandishing a sharp pick, they enter the water without a splash, resurfacing no more than five minutes later to the embrace of a pre-warmed towel. "All clear!" your diver says. <b>Cheers go up below at the sound of the engines at full power once more.</b>

<b>A perilous plunge!</b> Your expedition is walking a ridge of the rainforest interior, and has become entranced by the scintillating blue of 'Le Cotinga des Mezoas'. Perhaps it is the distraction of looking up at the extraordinary bird that causes someone to misstep. They fall suddenly through the floor, and tumble into fresh air, <b>only an elastic tangle of vines spares them the drop. The problem now is they are suspended above a ravine,</b> and it's a long way down...

<b>It's a sword-swishing masterclass!</b> Your champion contorts to cut the liana above their right arm, and once free, cuts one daringly close to the neck, so that with trapeze-like ripple they may dismount to the floor of the ravine. "Simple!" they declaim, straightening up, "follow me if you dare!" There are hoots and cheers from the gallery above as the rest swing down on lianas like an army of spider monkeys.

<b>A very lucky escape.</b> Trying to be cautious, your soldier makes a cut in one of the vines. The harness suddenly lurches down a further ten feet. Still it seems a long way down. Another cut, and they are in freefall towards the bottom of the gully. Though cushioned somewhat <b>the impact causes a nasty ankle injury.</b>

<b>You have lost one of your bravest.</b>The first cut is wild, and sends them into a second tumble: there are gasps from above as your soldier clutches desperately at foliage, but try as they might, they are unable to find anything to grip. The poor soldier pinwheels to the very bottom of the ravine.

<b>It turns out to be an enjoyable puzzle.</b> The knot in examined in tense silence, until the light of revelation falls across their face. A tug here, a loosening there, and then voila! A slipknot forms that allows a breezy absail to the foot of the gorge. Your escapalogist bows to the exultant gallery.

<b>An infuriating tangle!</b> —by the expression of your trapped expeditioner at least. Every tug seems to tighten the gordian knot further. "Just cut it at the root!" they shout up. "Are you sure?" "Absolutely." When the lianas are cut there are seconds of freefall before the impact, which while slightly cushioned— like a fork wrapped in spaghetti verdi — <b>results in a nasty back injury.</b>

<b>A deadly conundrum.</b> The unfortunate victim tries pulling different strands until one has an effect. The tangle of vegetation falls away but for a loop around the neck, which, only closing after a few seconds of freefall, <b>results in instant death.</b>

<b>Your ship is pinned on the razor-sharp coral</b> that fringes an underwater volcano. Since she has rolled on her side, freeing your ship will need surgical precision to prevent gallons of water flooding in. If you do not wish to <b>send a team of divers to cut the ship free,</b> you may instead be able to <b>make or use something clever</b> to break free.

<b>The bell rings true.</b> Despite plonking into the water at an angle to which it is unaccustomed— the ship being at a slant —the diving bell descends easily to the scene of your troubles. Through the little glass window, a forest of living pastel appears, of which some of the more beautiful examples are embedded in the hull. Once your divers have detached the lifelinks constraining your vessel, your crew are free to resume what is becoming a fascinating journey.

<b>Your divers take like fish to water,</b> having had some dive training with the navy. Still the others worry when after five or six minutes, they have not yet surfaced. Suddenly the boat begins to wobble— they have cut it free! Soon after, your heroes emerge from the water giddy and glistening, and brandishing the magnificent coral in their hands.

<b>They can barely hold their breath long enough</b> to reach the coral floor, and as such must cut the ship free in relays. Error creeps in to their work along with feelings of lightheadedness, and <b>one of the divers slices his foot open on a shank of coral.</b> Everyone is too absorbed in their task to notice, but once the ship is free and back at sea, the pustulent swelling of the man's foot becomes increasingly difficult to ignore...

<b>Although your medic does take immediate action,</b> vigorously scrubbing the wound and flushing with fresh water and vinegar, the coral cut takes a surprisingly long time to properly heal. "Do I die? Is this the end?" the injured officer complains, as if an invalid to be waited on hand and foot. The swelling eventually reduces, and everyone can get on with their lives.

<b>Someone puts bandages around the wounds in a haphazard fashion,</b> as if they were mere scratches. "Change the bandages every few days" is the advice, but the abcess that has formed beneath soon bursts and the vile infection spreads. <b>He dies in his sleep.</b> For the others, their negligence will forever remain a source of great shame, for no man is an island, and the death of each man diminishes the whole.

<b>The diver develops a fever.</b> The abscess does not disappear, and a nasty infection spreads up the arm causing it to become swollen. He will be of no use on the ship for the remainder of the expedition, remaining an unpleasant reminder of the officers' inhuman disregard for the welfare of their crew.

<b>It's clumsy.</b> Out of breath and struggling weakly against a strong current, your divers bludgeon blindly at the coral, sending clouds of particles up through the water. Little do they realise how fragile the hull has become. Then one misplaced blow and it implodes, the water gushing in. The crew must count themselves lucky that the tide proceeds to sweep the unhappy vessel to shore. <b>It seems you have shipwrecked on a coral atoll</b>

<b>Your ship looks a sensation now she has coral poking from her keel.</b> Like doctors treating a foreign object, your fine craftsmen utilise a panoply of tools to reach under the hull and fragment the coral. They are then nimbly able to dress the wound in the hull before very much water gets in. The few naughty pieces of coral that remain wedged in the hull look rather fetching!

<b>They use a lot of spare materials, but it works.</b> Fighting the slant of the ship, they are able to fragment and push off the coral with a long pole they have constructed of wood, and rope and such. It is extremely heavy however, and as the ship judders free all your men cannot stop it from sliding into the sea. It feels like a waste, and there's only just enough left to repair the breach in the hull.

<b>There is a lot of head-scratching below deck,</b> as your confused carpenters try to fight the flood. They have neither tools nor creativity to do much more than smash the coral that has ripped through the ship. When the ship judders free, it has almost no buoyancy, and the crew count themselves lucky that it is swept ashore on the tide. <b>It seems you have shipwrecked on a coral atoll</b>

<b>Your diver takes like a fish to water,</b> having ample experience. Still the others worry when after five or six minutes, they have not yet surfaced. Suddenly the boat begins to wobble— it has been cut free! Soon after, your hero emerges from the water giddy and glistening, and brandishing magnificent coral in their hands.

<b>The accident with the coral reef as left the expedition shipwrecked on an atoll.</b> For a time your crew feel like children again— dancing along the sand and bathing in the sun, as they await a verdict on the damaged hull. When it comes, the news is not good— extensive repair is needed, and with supplies so short, there is considerable disagreement. Why <b>concentrate on repairs</b>, given how long that may take, when <b>scouting for food and water.</b>

<b>At the cry of "mines!", all rush to the prow.</b> Sure enough, several of the conical terrors bob seductively below. "Who knows how many of these infernal machines have passed us by, or yet await us. A false move, and this sea shall be a lake of fire! What the devil do we do?"

<b>"The way ahead is clear as the eye can see!"</b> says the delighted officer, folding up his telescope. As the last motes of fire trail down into the waves and fizzle, the crew can but admire such brave use of dynamite. "Better than fireworks!" says another, "The men have never been so entertained!"

<b>"We are masters of the sea!"</b> sing the triumphant crew, as the ship weaves easily beyond the last line of mines. "Even Odysseus, when faced with Scylla and Charybdis, lost men. We have lost none of our company, and our bonds only strengthen!" Soon, a special bottle is being uncorked, and toasts raised to the continued success of the expedition!

<b>"What was that noise?" gulps the helmsman,</b> but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.

<b>While at first plain sailing, the minefield is now gooey with danger.</b> A line of densely-packed mines stand between the ship and freedom. "With some makeshift device, we can clear the path ahead," explains the officer, "either that, or we just try our best to weave through it."

<b>"She survived! It worked!" calls the lookout,</b> as makeshift grapples trailing behind the little dinghy are able to hook the mines aside. Relief only comes, of course, once the expedition ship is clear of this last line of mines. "How did we get in such a pickle?" says one. "At least we're out of it," says another.

<b>A nervous sailor rows towards the line of mines.</b> The makeshift grappling hooks trailing behind his dinghy are intended to drag mines out of the path of the expedition ship. Unfortunately the sailor is a sacrificial goat. A grapple shatters the horns of a nearby mine, and the boat and its sailor explode in plume. Safe passage means nothing to those from whom a good friend was taken.

<b>The idea is a terrible one from the start.</b> The lengthy poles, comprised of other poles, are unwieldy and inaccurate, even in the hands of a several strong men. The crew's attempt to poke mines away when they draw near is suicide. Two booms come in succession, and a few feeble cheers at escape are drowned by the deafening wails. Few are left to bail water, when so many lie dead or injured.

<b>"What was that noise?" gulps the helmsman,</b> but fortunately a metallic scraping is not the prelude to a mighty boom. As the ship is fitfully steered betwixt the mines, hearts palpitate, and sailors wring sweat from their jerseys. When the all clear is finally given, there is not a sailor who fails to offer up a prayer to their goddess.

<b>The awfulness has barely begun.</b> Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. "Brace!" scream port-side, just prior to a portion of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who have lost many good sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.

<b>The awfulness has barely begun.</b> Restless waves conceal a thickening of the mines, and the ship's haphazard path makes impact inevitable. "Brace!" scream port-side, just prior to a portion of men and timber being propelled violently upward. That no further detonations follow is of little relief to a crew who have lost many good sailors, and sustained such significant damage to their ship.

<b>The search is a fruitful one.</b> The well-organised diplomatic library includes a comprehensive folio of papers on nearby mine positions. This enables the navigators to chart a safe course through the waters. The very same paper remarks that the mines were moored during the war, in order to protect a now-disused outpost. You stop by the outpost and pick up anything that looks useful.

<b>The search is worthwhile.</b> After a few hours scouring the diplomatic archives, a paper on nearby mine positions is found. This gives the navigators the difficult task of charting a safe course through the waters. No-one is quite sure if the information given is up-to-the-minute, but when the last line of mines is cleared, all are suitably relieved.

<b>The documents in the ship archives at first seem exact.</b> A map is discovered showing the mine positions. It is only once a course has been plotted, and your ship is sailing at speed on its supposedly safe track, that a magnificent bang has the whole crew scrambling. The speed seemed to soften the mine's devastation, but there is still a nasty hole in the hull. A second glance at the map shows it is rather out-of-date. The reckless blunder has cost no lives, but the significant task of repair greatly wearies the crew.

<b>Optimism makes way for abject terror,</b> as the map of mines that is found and used for navigation turns out to be completely false. Terrible detonations devastate the ship's timbers, and countless lives are lost. "Misinformation is worse than no information," an officer laments, as his tears bleed the ink of the erroneous chart, which as it happens, refers to a different stretch of water.

<b>A few saintly volunteers approach,</b> offering to scout back the way you came and ease your escape. Asked if they aren't afraid of the cone-shaped mines, they reply "The lord will see us through."

<b>The volunteers exude calm,</b> as their lone dinghy traces a path much akin to that which got you into this mess. Although their silent vigil transports you to safety, all agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.

<b>While the path the volunteers cut is a true one,</b> it does not account for the difference in size between the two ships. It only takes a narrow graze to explode one of the mines, and though no lives are lost, the damage to your ship is significant. The crew are dismayed by the situation.

<b>For the godless dinghy, doom seems inevitable</b> the moment it drops and a man slops overboard. This inauspicious beginning foreshadows the disaster to follow. Prayers unheard, steering in the rough current proves impossible. The little boat is last seen careening towards the sinister cones it sought to avoid. "The terrible loss of life shall remain with me all my days," says a devastated officer.

<b>It is horrifying that most significant members of the crew</b> are aboard this fragile dinghy. Of course one would not wish a mine to explode any loyal man, but when it bellows up below a collection of your finest, death stings all the more. The crew are understandably devastated at the destruction they have witnessed firsthand. Life feels as if it may never be the same again.
<b>Your faith goes untried</b> in the nervous silence, as the ship escapes the mine trap the same way it entered. All agree they should never have ended up in a minefield in the first place.

<b>Your faith does not go untried.</b> The sinister cones have moved about over time, and no matter how truly the ship follows its original course, it is inevitable a mine will burst into the hull. Luckily when the blast comes, no man dies. Still, the burdensome schedule of repair disheartens the crew.

<b>None of it is of any use.</b> Your godforsaken crew do not realise how the sinister cones move about over time. No matter how true the course, more than one mine shakes the ship's belly as it limps clear. Many lives are lost, and the damage to the ship is severe.

<b>The map of these endless dunes is a swindle.</b> The first officer turns to berate the guide from whom they were purchased, but the fellow is already gone, as if the sands had swallowed him up. A solitary well offers a slight dribble of consolation, but your men must otherwise come to terms with being rather lost.

<b>A local rider comes to the rescue.</b> He saunters over on his camel, and explains the well is part of a lost city, accessible over a small rise. The crew are enchanted by the grand quarry, swept over by the sands of time, observations of which shall no doubt bring them fame on their return. After proof of their remarkable discovery has been gathered, the rider is only too glad to lead the elated crew back to more familiar dunes.

<b>Clear desert nights are perfect for astronomers.</b> Beneath a black cloak lucid with the constellations, your expert navigators school the remainder in mankind's relation to the heavenly bodies. It is a moment of realisation for many. Enlightened, the crew return to the ship filled with the wonder of the desert and their place in the universe.

<b>Something of a path appears</b>, though as much by luck as star-gazing. A little way along it, a silhouette crenellates the night - an imposing fortress. Too tired for trouble, you wonder if it is worth knocking at the grand door.

<b>The occupant Sultan welcomes you in.</b> He introduces himself in his own tongue, and is impressed by your interpreters. "You are far from what you seek. Stay, replenish for the journey ahead." Thus the crew enjoy the Sultan's hospitality while they can, for it will ease the last stretch of their journey.

<b>You lack the means to communicate.</b> Believing you to be an invasion force, the paranoid Sultan orders hot oil be poured from the ramparts. There is no escaping for one, eaten alive by the molten cascade. Resuming your desert path is the only option. The journey is a wearying lament for a fallen friend, meandering slowly back to civilisation.

<b>It is a long and draining journey.</b> Finally the crew limp exhausted into a settlement, from where it will no doubt be possible to procure the appropriate charts. Most would be happy never to see those grumpy old camels ever again.
<b>The "stars are fickle", say your officers by way of excuse.</b> After traveling for a while, the familiar shape of the well appears in the darkness. Your men have been walking in a circle.

<b>The stars utterly perplex your party.</b> With romantic notions dashed, the crew look around for some landmark, but instead find a featureless wasteland. They are desperately lost. Water, food and hope are in increasingly short supply. But even in a desert, there must be a way...

<b>Desperate thanks are due to a dung beetle.</b> As it scuttles along, those less capable in coleopterology cast doubt on the value of pursuing it. There is a minor scuffle in the sand before at last the bloody-nosed experts are listened to. The jolly beetle leads to owl dung, and owls in turn to farmland. Thus the embittered and exhausted crew are saved from desiccation.

<b>A wild goose chase to desolation.</b> Though the ostrich your crew have found cannot fly, it lollops along at surprisingly high speed. They try in vain to follow, but the sun is twice its usual size, and the bird is gone. Hot sand melts soles, and feet begin to swell. The water is out. Those that make it must have some evolutionary adaptation, because for most the desert is to be their graveyard.
<b>Your reprobates have no knowledge of desert mysteries.</b> The divining rod has wasted enough of your time, and your caravan is nearly through the water.

<b>A pretty price for divine mercy.</b> The Y-shaped stick leads all on a meandering path. One insists on stopping to dig, and is left behind. It is a wasted, and fatal effort. After two days of hardship, the rest stumble over a crest to discover the wide blue sea, their mocking ship upon it.

<b>The sun is unspeakably hot.</b> As the bedraggled lumber back to civilisation, there are wiltings among them. It is too much for the others to turn their heads. Bodies slumping to ash and dust, lost to the waves of a powder sea.

<b>Star of wonder, star of light!</b> Your wise magi are stirred by an unusually bright celestial body, that is surely a sign! It foretells a spiritual pilgrimage through the desert leading to a garden of eden. A grove of flowing streams, orange and incense, where like-minded devotees congregate. Your crew feel blessed, and the expedition can resume with new-found devotion.
<b>Are the gods testing you?</b> You wait and wait but there is not yet a sign.
