Discouraged, the crew is forced to return to Isabel's island. "We lost them" apologises the captain. But a few days later, Isabel receives a letter from one of her scouting parties, 'Pyrphorian vessel spotted entering Montoya harbour." With renewed hope, the crew prepares to leave at once. <b>The contract and those Pyrphorians must be here in Montoya, but where?</b> The city sprawls before you under a pastel blue sky, the distinctive whitewall and terracotta of Imperial La Corona glowing softly all along the narrow estuary where the Mixcoatl meets the ocean. Yet, tranquil it is not. Anxiety is written in every passing face. They must know who you are and what you seek, but finding one brave enough to share is a different matter. You can ask around, or rely instead on your own eyes to find clues.

The sole survivor succeeds in getting back to Isabel's island. In his panic, he explains that the rest didn't make it, and describes how he traced the enemy back to an estate outside Montoya. A crew is assembled at once. They arrive to find the Casona looks quite modern, with its white walls and pleasant gables. <b>The Prosperity contract must be here.</b> An adjoining orangery extends naturally towards the neat parterres of a sweet-smelling garden. An arc of white gravel serves as a drive, and long lines of equally white picket border the acreage in typical colonial style. Indeed were it not for the unusual height of this perimeter, and the shelters abutting it at intervals— armed guards no doubt stationed in each— it would appear much as any other estate. You consider your plan of entry.

<b>It is no coincidence that the trail of roses in Her Majesty's wake has ended in this pretty continental town.</b> What can have caused her to cross a narrow sea, poppy-flecked fields, and mythical river valleys? She has not simply waltzed over for the ambience— this is the heartland of her maternal family line, and she is here with a purpose.

<b>A nearby castle or country residence, of course!</b> "Eliminate all other factors, and what remains is the truth," as the sleuths say, and the Queen would never be content to stay in town. Calculating you are no more than two days behind the Queen's retinue, you are able to draw a circle on a map around suitably regal stopovers. <b>It is now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...</b>

<b>Your familiarity with the Teutonic dynasties stands you in good stead.</b> Whispers at home are growing ever louder on the subject the Queen's suitors, and her cousin Ernest seems to be one of the front-runners. You visit the outspoken prince consort at his ivy-clad burg, and having presented a letter Sir Archibald gave you, he nods and leads you through its low, rib-vaulted ceilings, past gilt-candelabras and canvas portraits. <b>Though cordial, Prince Ernest seems a little twitchy.</b>

<b>You know it's the wrong choice from the moment you walk into the parlour.</b> The Duchess, who is of middle-age, lies half-asleep in a four-posted bed, which from her dishevilled appearance it seems she has not left in days. "Excuse my zurprise," she croaks, "But a Queen, come here? When our zide of the family has been neglected for years?" She feigns a tortured expression. "But now we have darling visitors!" Anxious not to offend, you remain in her company until she eventually tires of her games. She lets slip the Queen is visiting her cousin, Prince Ernest. <b>The Prince offers you a cordial welcome at his ivy-clad castle, but appears twitchy throughout.</b>

"From your movements, I sense that you too are worried for her welfare." <b>The subtlety of your deduction surprises Prince Ernest.</b> He nods silently, and falls heavily into the ornate chair behind his desk. "She asked me to help trace our shared lineage— to establish the validity of certain claims she has through her ancestral ties to La Corona." Ernest pauses and crunches nervously on some recently-acquired shortbread. "She had wanted to do it alone for once. But she risks herself, and I have now decided you must go after her— <b>There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there.</b>

<b>Your strange deduction offends Prince Ernest.</b> "From your movements, I sense this is a matter of the heart," is what you had said. Prince Ernest had then turned his back on you gothically, shouting — "How dare you; prying into her personal affairs, as they all did during the crushing confines of her youth!" — before storming into the gardens to sulk. The next day the Prince seems only very slightly calmer, "she asked me to help trace our family tree— that is all. I will not stop you going after her, in spite of your impertinence, only because I am concerned for her welfare. <b>There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there."</b>

<b>You can't imagine where she could have stayed in this town,</b> pretty as it may be. You leave and take the road south, stopping beside an orchard to rest. Your knowledge of local dialect is passable enough to overhear fruit-pickers talking about a recent and distinguished visitor. <b>Curious, you ask them if they are referring to your Queen, at which they fall silent.</b> It seems they must have sworn to secrecy.

<b>Your authoritative presence unsettles them into confessing all they know,</b> which frankly, being fruit-pickers, isn't much more than you. Although one thing they have heard is that the Queen will be staying in luxury with family — a country residence, or castle with pointy tourelles, no doubt. <b>It is now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...</b>

<b>The fruit-pickers don't believe you are who you threaten to be,</b> and if anything, your surly attitude makes them wonder if it could be you the Queen is running away from. They call out to the rest of the pickers, who stand shoulder-to-shoulder with them in case you should think of taking things any further. Turning miserably back to your carriage in the road, it is only after considerable soul-searching that you re-read Sir Archibald's briefing, "despite her secrecy, a Queen never travels humbly." Of course, how stupid! One of the countless castles that dominate the hills all around. <b>It is now but a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...</b>

<b>They accept your offer, "she stay with family— at ze castle!"</b> You are astonished to learn that the Queen dragged her skirts through the mud of the orchard, insisting that all her finely-dressed footmen should be fed and watered, and that no-one should know she or her retinue were there. One of the pickers you bribed laughs, emulating her speech, "I hope you don't zink me too bohemian a Monarch." His friend reminds him with a sharp nudge that mocking the Queen might not be the best idea. <b>It is now just a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...</b>

<b>They refuse.</b> Clearly the fear of divine retribution against those who defy royalty is too strong. They call out to the rest of the pickers, who stand shoulder-to-shoulder with them in case you should want to take things any further. You turn miserably back to the carriage in the road, and it is only after hours of hopeful meandering in this beautiful country that you recall Sir Archibald's briefing, "despite her secrecy, a Queen never travels humbly." Of course, how stupid! One of the countless castles that dominate the hills all around. <b>It is just a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...</b>

<b>They don't take much convincing to tell you what they know,</b> especially when you seem so sympathetic to the challenges of peasant life; "Passing foreign Queens expect your silence for nothing, and yet it is you who must die in the fields for your masters when the harvest has failed." They grumble in recognition, noting that the Queen thought the town beneath her, and went off to stay in a nearby castle. <b>It is now just a question of exactly which of her landed relatives she came here to visit...</b>

<b>The locals are stubborn in their silence.</b> The Queen is a relative of those who own the land they work, and they fear for their livelihoods. There are further confirmations that the Queen passed through however, which lead you to the unlikely environs of a cider orchard. Two likely-looking pickers stand at the gate, both unable to disguise that they have recently met royalty, or that they have promised to say nothing to that matter.

<b>You sneak upon proof it is her cousin Ernest she was visiting.</b> While the Prince's welcome is polite, his stiffness of manner alerts your suspicions. And when, after tea, he gives you the freedom of the ivy-clad castle, you waste no time seeking signs she was there. You find paper on the desk in a guest bedroom impressed with quill-marks, and make a rubbing. A letter from the queen to her handmaid! It largely concerns itself with Ernest's handsome looks.<b>When you rasie the subject with Prince Ernest, he becomes rather twitchy.</b>

<b>You are led a merry dance.</b> It transpires the Queen has made several visits to family in the region, staying very briefly at each estate before being driven on to the next with her modest retinue. You try to puzzle the ultimate purpose of this, but can deduce nothing, and must go around the houses before you arrive exhausted at the ivy-clad castle of Consort Prince Ernest. <b>His nervous disposition suggests he knows the Queen's intentions in visiting.</b>

<b>"Very well," agrees the Prince,</b> once your persuasive speech has come to an end, "My dear cousin asked me to help trace our shared lineage— to establish the validity of certain claims she has through ancestral ties to La Corona." He removes a map of the continent from his neatly-arranged bureau. "Your diplomatic immunity may prove important in the days ahead. What she plans may put her at risk." He sighs. <b>"There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there."</b>

<b>You have lost some face in royal circles.</b> "I shall tell you nothing, nothing!" Prince Ernest says curtly, exhausted by your chatter, "yet another prying into her personal affairs, as so many did through the crushing confines of her youth!" The Queen's cousin then storms into the gardens to sulk. The next day he seems only very slightly calmer, "she asked me to help trace our family tree— that is all. I will not stop you going after her, in spite of your impertinence, only because I am concerned for her welfare. <b>There is to be a masked ball in Monégasque. You will find her there."</b>

<b>Following Prince Ernest's advice, you travel by train along the sparkling Côte Turquoise to a grand station in the sophisticated principality of Monégasque.</b> Ruled for six centuries by the Piedmont family, today the streets of Monégasque are filled with colour and light, for it is the grand opening of its very first casino! The theme is animal masquerade, and you see disturbing furred and feathered costumes at every turn. Convenient for a Queen going incognito... <b>Prince Ernest gave you his own invitation to the casino, but you will also need a costume.</b>

<b>You can't help but feel you paid rather a lot for the last-minute tailoring,</b> which in fairness the costumier hammers out with astonishing calm. You get changed and observe the result in the long mirror — what you see is reminiscent of Alice's cheshire cat, or better, that pussy cat famously employed to fetch royal mice. <b>You meow past the casino doormen, and once inside, debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>
<b>The costumier turns up her lips in disgust.</b> It seems you can't afford to pay the going rate for a last-minute costume, so <b>you'll have to meet the casino dress code in some other way.</b>

<b>Your knowledge of royalty does not desert you;</b> in a circle of the most elegantly-dressed people, you spy a beautiful sequined elephant, in whose hand is a foul mixture of claret and malt whisky— the Queen's favourite. Your eyes meet, and hers widen. She drops her glass, and there are gasps as she rushes for the exit. By the time you have forced your way outside, <b>her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.</b>

<b>You can't tell anyone here apart,</b> as far as you are concerned, they might as well all be princes, queens and kings! Suddenly a silence falls, and the Prince of Monégasque himself— a man with an improbably thin moustache, makes a long speech about how the casino will bring back the good times for the Piedmont family. "And finally, I notice we have a special guest," he smiles, at which a sequined elephant promptly rushes for the door, "but, oh your majesty, wait!!" But by the time you have forced your way outside, <b>her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.</b>

<b>Your luck does not desert you,</b> and soon among those drawn to your blessed table, you spy a beautiful sequined elephant. Your eyes meet, and hers widen. She must recognise you! There are gasps as she rushes for the exit. By the time you have forced your way outside, <b>her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.</b>

<b>Your luck is dreadful,</b> and you are so preoccupied with the roulette wheel, you fail to notice that your Queen is indeed present. Suddenly a silence falls, and the Prince of Monégasque himself— a man with an improbably thin moustache, makes a long speech about how the casino will bring back the good times for the Piedmont family. "And finally, I notice we have a special guest," he smiles, at which a sequined elephant promptly rushes for the door, "but, oh your majesty, wait!!" But by the time you have forced your way outside, <b>her carriage has set off at speed. You wave another cab down, and get in.</b>

<b>Cunning and resourceful,</b> you acquire and combine every accoutrement needed to give you the appearance of a fox. Twirling your catgut whiskers, and dashing up the marble steps, <b>you brush slyly past the casino doormen, and once inside, debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>A shambolic cow costume!</b> You could barely have come up with anything less voguish. The doormen are too serious to laugh, and instead escort you to one side, "this is a society event! It doesn't matter who you are, you can't come in dressed like that!" If you are going to get in and find the Queen, <b>you'll have to settle for a less fashionable route.</b>

<b>A few heads turn, but the doormen don't stop you.</b> "I'm a special guest of the Piedmont family," you say with a winning smile, as you brandish the invitation Prince Ernest gave you, "expected to donate great sums to the cause. So you can forgive my choice of attire." One of the doormen hands you a black eye mask, which you put on, reserved no doubt for exceptional circumstances such as this. <b>Once inside the casino, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>It seems they will make no exceptions.</b> "This is a society event," says the doorman in exasperation, "it doesn't matter who you are, you can't come in dressed like that!" If you are going to get in and find the Queen, <b>you'll have to settle for a less fashionable route.</b>

<b>You show off your powers of mystery.</b> As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you are hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. There is a bathroom window open up above. The stucco holds as you shimmy up unseen, swinging your legs over the threshold. <b>Finally inside the casino, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>Not as stealthy as you had imagined.</b> As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you are hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. You scale the wall without incident, but then accidently trip through a skylight. You crunch onto the rug of a guest bedroom in a rain of shattered crystal. Luckily the guest is downstairs playing craps and will not discover this mess until much later. Trying to summon whatever remaining grace you have, <b>you make your way inside the casino and debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>You show your strength.</b> As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you are hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. The doorman on this side looks feeble. You walk up to him and pop him on the nose, take his plain black eye mask for yourself, and saunter into the casino. <b>Once inside, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>Unfortunately, it's a pretty even contest.</b> As you stalk around to the promenade behind the casino, you are hit by a warm riviera breeze and the sight of exotic palms. The doorman on this side looks muscular, at least compared to you. You take a swing at him, catching him by surprise, but he comes back hard, and a scuffle develops. "I yield," he says finally. Dusting yourself off, you take his plain black eye mask to cover your black eyes and bloody nose, and shamble into the casino. <b>Once inside, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>"Very well," agrees the doorman,</b> "the Prince of Monégasque kindly accepts your donation, and wishes you should have a fine evening at his casino." <b>Once inside, you debate your best bet for finding the Queen.</b>

<b>"No, no," one of the doormen shakes his head,</b> "the Prince of Monégasque would not accept such a donation. I am under strict instructions only to admit those in suitable costume." <b>It seems you'll have to settle for a less fashionable route.</b>

<b>The Queen fled the casino at speed,</b> and your own carriage is some distance behind. Your driver thinks she is headed up the coast, perhaps to a ship. <b>You can either keep up your pursuit, or else rush to your own ship,</b> which, if the orders you gave to the captain have been followed, should be waiting in the Monégasque marina.

<b>You reach the next bay up from Monégasque,</b> and hopping out of your carriage, see the Queen bustling along a jetty at which a great flagship dubbed "Lap of Victory" is moored. Obviously she has primed them for such an emergency, as they all seem ready to go. <b>You can try to call out to the Queen, or else borrow a vessel to continue your pursuit.</b>

<b>You comport yourself with dignity,</b> "Your Majesty, please, I'm not here to seize you, but to assist you in any way I am able!" The short rotund figure turns, dresses in hand, and a small but shrill voice floats back towards you over the sound of the sea. <b>"Meet me at the Cape of Trelawney!"</b> You find your own ship at the marina, and sail to Trelawney, southernmost point of the Old World. It was not fifteen years previous, that a great naval victory was won here over La Corona by one Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you warmly aboard. <b>You are finally able to ask her why it is she has run away.</b>

<b>You cannot keep the irritation from your voice,</b> "Your Majesty, please, desist from this charade!" The short rotund figure turns, dresses in hand, and a small but defiant voice floats cuts the sound of the sea. "I am not a child, I am your Queen! Be at the Cape of Trelawney tomorrow, or else." You slink off to find your ship at the marina and head for Trelawney, southernmost point of the Old World, where not fifteen years previous, a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. The Lap of Victory is there waiting for you, and the Queen receives you rather icily aboard. With a gulp, <b>you are finally able to ask why it is she has run away.</b>

<b>"Your helmsmanship is most impressive!"</b> the Queen calls down to you, as you bring the modest sailing ship you have borrowed neatly alongside her flagship.<b>"Meet me tomorrow at the Cape of Trelawney!"</b> You find your own ship at the marina, and sail to Trelawney, southernmost point of the Old World. <b>"A limp effort!"</b> the Queen bellows down to you, as you bring the leaky fishing boat you have stolen alongside her gigantic flagship. Rather than leave you to flounder, she seems to have taken pity on you and slowed down.<b>"Meet me at the Cape of Trelawney, and good heavens, bring a proper vessel!"</b> You slink off to find your ship at the marina and head for Trelawney, southernmost point of the Old World, where not fifteen years previous, a great naval victory was won over La Corona by the heroic Admiral Nadasky. <b>Your ship is indeed waiting in the marina.</b> Quickly, you rouse the captain and his crew, and weigh anchor. Before long, twinkling Monégasque is behind you, and from the next bay, you spot an impressive ship in the distance. How was she able to leave port so fast? <b>You either can continue to chase Her Majesty, or send her a message of peace with your signal lamp.</b>

It is late summer when the expedition reaches the Tchilling Sound, and yet <b>the conditions in these icy seas are already challenging.</b> The wind only has to pick up, and the men are tugging up their collars and tramping below. It seems hopeless to think Sir John Faithful's men could have lasted three winters here. Beyond Tchilling Sound, the seaway divides. <br /><b>To the west</b> lie a chain of small islands separated by partially melted ice. <br /><b>To the south</b>, a long, dark headland crowned with snow, that hazes out of sight.

<b>The first severe blizzard.</b> You have just caught sight of the Baffling Island littoral, when the headwind suddenly whips up and a dark fringe of cloud appears in the heavens. All take cover below deck, as rock-hard pellets of ice begin to pelt the ship with such force as to cause lasting damage. <b>"We've lost control of her," screams the navigator,</b> but it'd take a hero to go back out into that.

<b>Worthy heroes step forward.</b> "Whatever this ship and her crew needs," says the burliest, before striding out into the storm. Undeterred by the snow and buffeting of the wind, they put the sails 'in their gear'— loosing the sheetlines, and pulling the buntlines through, until the ship is running under jib alone. <b>The storm passes, and the crew feel invincible.</b>

<b>Not easy handling sails at minus thirty,</b> and while those brave enough to take on the ice storm are strong enough, their labour is clumsy. As the snowblasted sails are loosened, your men allow them to catch a crosswind and suddenly they are off! Flapping wildly against a creaking mainmast, <b>the sails are threatening to rip half the ship away.</b>

<b>Twang! The sails flap away into dark drifts of snow.</b> Your able-footed sailor reaching every rope without slip, and the snowflakes crowding his eyes unable to prevent the skillful execution of his art. Next day the Arctic sky is still once more. <b>"The mast is intact, and we've spare rope and sail," says the carpenter, "we'll be all right."</b>

<b>Your men cannot keep their footing</b> for the ice on deck, and the hard rocking of the ship gives them further excuse to lower their swords. They can only watch as, under the pull of the sails, the mainmast cracks open like grissini, the upper section cartwheeling out to sea, a tangle of rigging behind it. The crew are all accounted-for, but<b> the damage to the ship</b> is probably irreparable.

<b>The mainmast takes much of the brunt,</b> whipped and contorted in every direction by the impassioned sails. When the storm and seizures finally end, <b>the carpenter tallies the cost of your inaction.</b> "There's fissures in the mast. It may hold with enough resin, then again, maybe not..."

<b>A bunch of wet lettuces.</b> They claim that the rigging is too slippery to grip. If these are your best sailors, lord help the others, but those sails must come down— the ship is being blown towards some jagged silhouette! You can <b>grab something to aid the climb</b> or <b>get them up there quick.</b>

<b>At least no-one dies.</b> The crew raid stores for ropes and chains so as to climb the rigging safely, before stowing the sails away. The ship slows but does not completely halt, colliding with that silhouette — a small and craggy island — and damaging the hull. <b>The crew have some lengthy repairs ahead of them.</b>

<b>A disaster of their own fashioning.</b> Instead of finding a proper solution, the crew hurriedly don standard-issue gloves. The leather is so smooth in the palm, it is worse than climbing with no gloves at all. The ship lurches inexorably into that silhouette— a hideously craggy isle — and the impact flings the gripless riggers into the water. Visibility is so poor, and the water so cold, that <b>there's no hope of saving those gone overboard.</b>

<b>Filled with doubt, they do as instructed.</b> The conditions are dreadful, and they can barely see to work in the sideways slather and what with the waves buffeting the ship. A man falls from the upper rigging, and is found to be only loosely intact. "What are you trying to prove?!" bellows the navigator above the whine of the wind. Finally, the sails are put up and the boat can ride out the remainder of the storm without blowing off course. <b>Your crew are incensed at the coldness of their superiors.</b>

<b>Faith and prudence.</b> Your sailors huddle below, rocked hard, but out of harm's way. They resist the temptation to attend the creaking ship and its rudder and trust their course to the divine. Soon the grog is flowing, sailors play at cribbage, and all forget where they be. "Hold! I hear no storm," a sailor says suddenly. The hatch is opened to reveal stillness and stars, and <b>a harlequin snake of an aurora, smiling down benevolent.</b>

<b>Your sailors will not wait for god.</b> The storm shrieks its name, as sailors muttered frenzied supplications to the nameless. "To hell and damn you all, I want to die living," the others bellow at them, and so unchained, they rush out into the white. Harsh commands can be heard above, before those voices fall silent. Somehow the ship rides out the storm, but <b>the bodies of your saviours are never found.</b>

<b>You have a hardy legion indeed.</b> They rush to the tarpaulins, and with commendable teamwork and physical strength in the challenging conditions, are able to pull them over the ship's most sensitive instruments and machinery. Heading below deck to relax, <b>the heroes wait out the storm in luxury</b> with buttered currant buns and hot tea.

<b>Their defence of the ship is a little half-hearted.</b> Initially the men show willing, but the blizzard quickly wears them down, and they retreat inside claiming that their work is done. After the worst of it has passed, the officers survey the ship. Beneath a poorly affixed and feeble tarpaulin, the engine is found flooded with slush that must now be cleared. <b>One has to wonder if they are cut out for these kinds of challenges.</b>

<b>Tragic youthful over-exuberance.</b> Your sailors drain a bottle of strong rum before going back out, perhaps believing machismo will keep them warm. They batten the hatches in the white flurry, stumbling, belching and laughing. The hilarity continues when one of the lads slips and loses his feet, that is until the steel rim of the funnel meets his head with a clomp. <b>He dies instantly.</b>

<b>The thrill-seeking diver relishes the task.</b> Covering themselves in bear fat and brandishing a sharp pick, they enter the water without a splash, resurfacing no more than five minutes later to the embrace of a pre-warmed towel. "All clear!" your diver says. <b>Cheers go up below at the sound of the engines at full power once more.</b>

<b>"Sir!" cries the lookout, "dark shapes on the ridge!"</b> A group climb the icy escarpment. At the top they find a companionable trio of driftwood boards plugged in three man-sized heaps of snow. Sunlight hits the scritchings in the wood, "Sacred to the memory of Joseph Braine, who departed this life New Year's Day 1846 on board of H.M. Styx." The others named are "John Gore" and "Francis Seeley." <b>Your men tremble at the idea of disturbing the graves.</b>

<b>The crew agree to draw lots.</b> A scrawny man gets the shovel, and clears snow to reveal Braine's face, who might look asleep but for his skin of leather. In his pocket, a letter to his wife. <i><br/><font  overrideTextColor="true" color='#695c4c'>Dearest Elaine,<br/> I've few breaths left. I die never having found a Passage, but then no glory awaits any servant of Sir John. He was certain the ice would not thicken around us in Spring. Fate of expedition now rests on circumnavigation of Terrier Island by short, perilous west shore, or by long, open east channel— fear I know what Sir John will prefer. <br/>Farewell my Elaine.</font></i>

A hundred metres from the graves, <b>the men find the remains of a camp</b> at which the lost expedition wintered. They built a cairn— a stack of stones— under which a tin cylinder containing a tightly-rolled letter is found. "They left a note of their progress," the captain says. Lady Faithful recognizes her husband's handwriting.<br/><font  overrideTextColor="true" color='#695c4c'><i>May 28th, 1847 { H.M. ships 'Styx' and 'Hades' wintered in the ice in lat. 70˚ 05' N ; long. 98˚ 23' W. Having wintered in 1846-7 at Baffling Island, in lat. 74˚ 43' 28" N., long. 91˚ 39' 15" W., after having sailed Wailing Channel to lat. 77˚, and returned by the west side of Cornell Island. Total loss by deaths to this date has been 3 men due to sickness — Braine, Gore and Seeley, God rest their souls. Leaving tomorrow for Terrier Island. Aim to reach Passage by end June; we must be close now. John Faithful, Commander, HMS Styx.</i></font>
The ship is now headed for the West coast of Terrier Island. The crew hope to find Sir John and his men soon, and they pray no more obstacles will come their way.
The ship is now headed for the East coast of Terrier Island. The crew hope to find Sir John and his men soon, and they pray no more obstacles will come their way.

As you near the coast, a large human construction delineates itself, <b>"Most probably an abandoned trading post of the Huddlesome Bay company."</b> It leans hard into the wind, its once-red boards scoured pale. If Sir John and his crew came this way, they would likely have stopped here. "What of getting there, sir?" says the ship's boy. He has noticed that <b>an ice sheet lies between your ship and the trading post.</b>

<b>Your crew's instincts are solid.</b> Keeping a distance apart, they move at a purposeful speed, avoiding cracks and the dark splodges indicative of thinner ice. They reach the abandoned building without incident.

<b>Knowledge is shaky.</b> One of your groups avoids the gaping holes, but fails to notice darker patches of thin ice. Cracking can be heard, but none of the group dare move. They hit the water with a woosh as the brûlée snaps. It is freezing, and they are struggling to climb out alone. <b>If not rescued quickly they'll die of hypothermia.</b>

<b>The rope team keep balance.</b> Lying down, and spreading out to distribute the weight, they throw ropes to those in the water, who thrash to bind themselves under the armpits. On a count of three, they are hoisted clear of the water. <b>Wet and chattering with cold,</b> your expedition takes refuge in the old trading post.

Forget strength, <b>what they needed was teamwork.</b> The rope team disregard their own safety and pull as they would on dry land. The ice can't hold, and collapses beneath them. Some manage to crawl free of the water and save themselves but <b>others slip away</b> to fertilise the ocean bed. The survivors trudge for the thin comforts of the disused trading post.

<b>They make it. They're okay!—</b> cheered across the line in a spirit akin to the finish of a cross-country at school back home. Nobody left behind then, and nobody left behind now. <b>Wet and chattering with cold,</b> your expedition take refuge in the abandoned building, offering up prayers of gratitude.

To those in the water <b>the encouragement sounds noticeably strained.</b> Convulsing as they slip down between part-frozen cuboids, their resolve fades with the voices, the light above ever more distant. <b>Knowing they could have done more,</b> the survivors trudge for the thin comforts of the disused trading post.

<b>The ship's carpenters improvise with a rotary drill.</b> It takes a fair bit of effort to get it turning, suggesting the ice is pretty solid. The first measurement is 11 inches— no hazard even for a sizeable group to pass over. Every few steps a new reading is taken, but it proves a mere formality, since the readings change very little. <b>They make the abandoned building without incident.</b>

<b>It was never going to work,</b> using a heavy, blunt instrument to make his hole. Lucky as it happens, that the carpenter is alone as his sledgehammer comes down, sundering the ice all about him and casting him into the freezing water. Turns out the ice is fairly thick, but that won't save the poor fellow now. The others trudge for the thin comforts of the disused trading post in disbelief.

<b>The inevitable splosh.</b> Despite the cold wind, it is still summer in the Arctic, and the weight of a large group of bodies would test thicker ice than this. Halfway across the sheet, there is a rasping crack, and your men are deposited in the water. In their struggle to escape they have to kick off their snow boots. Chattering, they make it to the thin comfort of the abandoned trading post with <b>their feet in a terrible state.</b>

<b>"At least it's a shelter,"</b> the captain remarks. The men shut the doors on the wind, to find the building interior licked with frost. Rusted hooks hang from the beams, relics of the short-lived fur trade. "Comforts are few and far between out here, I doubt Sir John would have passed it by." <b>There must be some evidence of the lost expedition here.</b>

<b>No sign at all.</b> Undisturbed in ten years or more, these cabins are just as they were when the traders left. There should be prints in the dust, objects out of place, but there aren't. Everyone concedes <b>it is very unlikely Sir John's expedition came this way.</b>

<b>Something to go on at least.</b> Whoever the fur traders were they left in a rush. Papers and maps are strewn about, some trodden and sodden into mush, a precious few dry and intact. Dockets are found relating to consignments received from a nearby Inuit settlement named Ivujivik, which happens also to be marked on a fragment of map. "The Inuit are sure to have noticed anyone passing through," says the Captain, "we should visit them."

Standard.Name: Go back and head west - Add event

English.Text: The crew returns to the ship. Once at Tchilling Sound, they head west.

Standard.Name: Continue south toward the inuit settlement - Add event

English.Text: The crew marks the position of the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik on the map, and sets sail.

The route to the Inuit settlement of Ivujivik is <b>a two day trek by foot across exposed ice flats.</b> A small expedition party set off leaving the rest at sea to await their return.<br/>Although the going is tough, it is not this that preoccupies the crew. <b>As night falls, they are sure something has been following them.</b>

<b>Your sharp-eared watchman keeps vigil.</b> In the small dark of Arctic summer, he catches the scratch of a bear's unretractable claws on ice. It is trying to approach discretely but the watchman is ready. At the sound of his gun the rest wake with a jolt, only to find a big dead bear at his feet. <b>They celebrate their trophy, and are soon back en route to Ivujivik.</b>

<b>A mother polar bear!</b> Your watchman isn't used to such long days, struggling to keep his eyes open beside the hypnotic fire. A loud growl. Mother bear's claws dig deep into his spine and drags him off. <b>Moments later, and she is back for more!</b>

<b>Years of ambush drills pay off.</b> Quickly forming a circle your men level their guns into the half-light. Sensing the danger they pose, Mama bear grows more cautious, and after a single circuit of your camp, disappears out of sight. <br/>Full of adrenaline, <b>your scout party reach the Inuit camp.</b>

<b>Hands trembling with fear,</b> the men grab for their rifles, but mama bear smells their nerves and is upon them. Finally someone gets a shot away and though it misses, it scares her momentarily. Her white coat is lank with the blood of several men. Those still standing flee. The Inuit are startled when your party <b>arrive at Ivujivik the next afternoon looking especially bedraggled.</b>

<b>Your men know they have to stand tall</b> to face down a polar bear, and waving their coats above their heads like flags, they succeed in driving the bear away. Full of adrenaline, <b>your scout party reach the Inuit camp.</b>

<b>Mama bear looks angry.</b> Your men had assumed that staring might make her back down, but she has taken it as a display of aggression. Her white coat is soon lank with the blood of several men. Those still standing flee. The Inuit are startled when your party <b>arrive at Ivujivik the next afternoon looking especially bedraggled.</b>

<b>The men are strong and dedicated.</b> They tramp through the half hour of pitch darkness normally reserved for sleep, keeping good pace. Whatever was following them has soon given up. Gazing upwards the party find themselves to be lucky observers of the aurora borealis. <br/><b>They reach the Inuit settlement the following lunchtime, with a sense of wonder.</b>

<b>One of the men struggles to keep up</b> with his unsympathetic comrades. He is the runt, the weakest of the pack, and the polar bear knows it. The rest of the group hear a piercing scream followed by the sound of crunching and tearing. Moments later <b>mama bear is bounding across the snow towards them, hungry for more!</b>

Ivujivik is a semi-permanent settlement. <b>The Inuit appear worried, but nevertheless offer your men every hospitality,</b> inviting them into a large iglu where they are served a hearty Suaasat— a meat stew— under the silent gaze of what feels like the whole village. A girl, Tapeesa, is able to translate, and the others warm up when the hear the story of your journey over the ice flats. Soon the subject turns to Sir John's lost expedition. <b>Tapeesa shows you items</b> that look like they belonged to Sir John's expedition.

<b>Silver cutlery embossed with the names Hades and Styx. These are from Sir John's expedition ships!</b> There are also cufflinks belonging to Sir John engraved with assorted marsupials, and a knife handle with the emblem of the Arctic council. Tapeesa says that about a year ago, some men came wanting to know about channels through the ice, and traded their things for information. <b>She points to the west coast of Terrier Island on your map.</b>

<b>Tapeesa patiently explains</b> that they traded with men like yours about a year ago. The men wanted to know about channels through the ice, and traded their things for information. <b>She points to the west coast of Terrier Island on your map.</b>

<b>Your ship is stranded on an iceberg!</b> It is night along the east coast of Terrrier Island. The meek light of your vessel seems to dissolve into the moonless blackness. Even at easy sail and under constant vigil, your ship runs the risk here, for slumbering ice giants leer from the darkness in all directions. "Dead ahead!" comes the cry, too late! A low growl shakes the boat, as a wave dumps it atop a berg— in the shape of an upturned molar— beaching it there. The ship is undamaged, if only it could be returned to the water...

<b>Nothing in nature can prevail against human endeavour,</b> it would seem. The crew watch with trepidation as the fuses burn down to the stick, before an ear-splitting series of detonations rings across the vastness, sundering the icy claws that had held your ship hostage. A small blizzard of debris blankets the deck, to the delight of all aboard, for they are free once more!

<b>Ice crumbles all around such firepower.</b> Any cannon that can be swiveled at the target is put to use, chipping away the ice dungeon into which the ship has become wedged until the way is clear. Then like a cheerful sea lion the fair vessel slips down an escarpment and plops back into the water. The crew cheer and continue on their way.

<b>The iceberg fights back.</b> Though the way is almost clear, the relentless cannonfire seems to have woken the ogre below, and to the horror of the crew the vast berg rolls slightly to one side. Great shards of ice detach and bounce over the deck, injuring your men. <b>Quick action is needed.</b>

<b>Your men signed up for such challenges,</b> and scarcely need telling what to do. Leaping down from the boat, they get behind her, knotting guy ropes as only rugged sailors can. All the while the berg rumbles suggestively, but it is your committed team who prevail. Once clear of the ice field, the crew will be able to treat their wounds.

<b>It's an uphill struggle.</b> The pitching of the unstable berg does not help a jot, as the men tumble and slide to find grip. Such is the effort required to pull the ship successfully down from the iceberg into the sea, no-one notices one of the teams is missing. It appears they have fallen through a thin part of the ice to their deaths.

<b>Your ship performs a rather messy dismount.</b> After that intial roll, the iceberg halts long enough to suggest it wants to stay in its new position. But then everything happens all at once. The berg spins violently, and the ship with it! The ship strikes the water at such an angle that very serious damage is done to much of the lee-side. Fortunately the crew come out unharmed.

<b>The crew assembles a dozen hardy levers to free the ship.</b> Flexible hickory planking is cut and reshaped into a wedges, before being inserted into the ice at intervals of five paces, until they surround the stern. On a count of three the men lift, and to their surprise so does the hull! Once it starts moving, there's no stopping it; and it clatters through all icy obstructions to the sea. Your sailors embrace, they have been very resourceful.

<b>The wrong wood is selected for the task.</b> It is a decorative mahogany veneer, stripped from the captain's cabin. "Whatever it takes," the captain says with laudable magnanimity, but the whole business is futile. Despite the wedges being placed in great number at the stern of the ship, no amount of pressure from the crew can encourage the ship to move since the levers lack the requisite spring. They'll need to find another way off this berg.

<b>Free of the Iceberg,</b> the crew manages to circumvent Terrier Island via its easterly shore. However they have found no trace of the lost expedition. You'll have to try the west coast.<br/>Sir John must have taken the risky option.

The west coast of Terrier Island is snaggled up with monstrous horns of ice. <b>Navigation is going to be tricky.</b> Will the narrows lead back once more to open water, or will your ship end up stuck? You can <b>navigate carefully</b>, <b>get a better view</b> of the channels from a nearby rock, or <b>send scouts ahead in rowboats</b> to see.

To their relief <b>your crew reaches open sea on the other side.</b> As there is a lack of consensus on magnetic north at this time, your navigators decide to ignore the compasses and trust their instincts, saving them a collision on more than one occasion.<br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>The compass readings are confusing.</b> After several wrong turns the crew realise magnetic north is not where they, or anyone else imagined. Your ship finds itself alongside the run-off of a sizeable glacier, which it being spring, is melting. There are cracks, then there is an almighty rumble as <b>the entire wall of ice threatens to separate and topple into the water!</b>

<b>Your crew escape!</b> In moments the masts are dropped almost horizontal to catch every last ounce of wind, and it is just, <i>just</i> enough extra speed to avoid the mountain of ice crashing down into the channel. Waves from this rare natural event form a new avenue leading <b>out to the open sea</b>.<br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>Your crew escape!</b> The engine room take the initiative ahead of orders the bridge and stoke the fires. The ship picks up just, <i>just</i> enough extra speed to avoid the mountain of ice crashing down into the channel. Waves from this rare natural event form a new avenue leading <b>out to the open sea</b>.<br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>Your navigators panic.</b> Though the sails catch the breeze, the menfail to adjust out from under the falling wall. Blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. <b>A death and several injuries result.</b> The rest are lucky that large waves from the icefall form a new avenue leading <b>out to the open sea</b>.<br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>They are too close to the falling ice wall.</b> Your engines are fired up but the resulting turn is not a sharp one. Blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. <b>A death and several injuries result.</b> You are lucky that giant waves from the icefall form an avenue of escape <b>out to the open sea.</b><br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>"Ha! Let it rain!"</b> the captain bellows, as blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. <b>Your powerful vessel surges through to safety!</b> Waves from the icefall form a new avenue leading <b>out to the open sea.</b><br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>Your ship is no icebreaker.</b> There are cries as blocks of ice the size of cows tumble onto the deck and explode to powder. <b>A death and several injuries result.</b> You are lucky that giant waves from the icefall form an avenue of escape <b>out to the open sea.</b><br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>The men are used to hard climbs like these</b> and are up in no time to survey the labyrinth ahead. They report back with an easy route forward that leads to open sea once more.<br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...
<b>Your men say the climb is too steep,</b> or at least, no-one is daredevil enough to attempt it with the limited equipment they have. <b>Everyone is exasperated. You must find another solution.</b>

<b>Follow the seals, that's the answer!</b> Seals and more besides. From their rowboats your scouts are even able to follow a baleen whale as she surfaces for air. She leads them to open water, and your expedition ship follows. <br/><br/>The crew enters King William Sound, a majestic carpet of water leading up to its seat, King William Island. <b>Sensing something, Lady Faithful suddenly emerges from below deck,</b> and voices the determined hopes of her heart...

<b>No-one returns with a definitive clue.</b> "Ivory gulls were circling above what looks like a large glacier," says one, "it may lead us to open water..." It's the best you've got, but soon your ship finds itself alongside the run-off of a sizeable glacier, which it being spring, is melting. There are cracks, then there is an almighty rumble as <b>the entire wall of ice threatens to separate and topple into the water!</b>
Your captain awaits your command
It's too cold.
found a warm place!

Choose location to search

Found it!
You found some mysterious item
You have discovered new flora! The crew toast the success of your botanical expedition. Scents never sniffed before perfume the docks.
You have discovered new plant species! The wonderful exotic smell perfumes the air.
You have discovered new plant species! The wonderful exotic smell perfumes the air.

<b>You dock at a small lively port on the northern coast.</b> While most of your crew replenish supplies and repair damage suffered in a recent storm, some decide to explore the local souq.<br/><br/>Streets fold and unfold into each other, bedecked in a wild array of colours and wafting dizzyingly heady scents which so confuse your sailors that they become lost in the weave of passages. Seeing their distress, <b>several young men in beggarly clothes offer to guide them through the maze.</b>

It takes some observation, but <b>your sailors soon understand that the mosaic of low-hanging cloths are arranged in specific patterns.</b> A sharp right after a spice dealer’s enthusiastic attempt to sell your crew a few years’ worth of ochre and red powders leads them to a small shadowed plaza where two musicians are strumming many-stringed zithers of rich honeyed wood.<br/>There is a peacefulness to this place that soothes your crew, and they try to engage the musicians in conversation to learn more about their culture.<br/>

<b>Your crew’s linguistic efforts attract much appreciative surprise,</b> and a lively conversation soon sparks up, supplemented by voluminous approximative sign language and much laughter.<br/>Before your sailors can object, an intricate tea set is brought out and the small pewter cups are brimming with steaming crisp-scented mint tea, supplemented by flavourful pastries. Many tales are traded, and nightfall is well past when your crew return to ship, arms laden with simple but intricate tokens of friendship.<br/>

<b>Your crew barely knows enough of the language to greet the locals,</b> let alone to carry their questions. After long minutes of polite puzzlement they courteously but pointedly turn away. Frustrated, your crew retreat to the ship, hoping the next port encountered will be slightly more cosmopolitan.

Not wishing to interrupt the music, <b>one sailor walks up to a man about to enter a nearby house and taps his shoulder</b> to attract his attention. The man turns a curious face to this unexpected intervention.

<b>The man’s face darkens with anger.</b> He barks a few clearly offensive words and strides across the threshold, slamming the door in your crew’s baffled faces. Judging by the condemning stares they now attract, your sailors understand the gesture they made is considered a great insult, and wisely decide to retreat to the ship before committing another faux pas.

<b>The man starts unpleasantly, visibly insulted,</b> before casting a witheringly contemptuous glare at your expectant crew.  Judging by the condemning stares they are suddenly attracting your sailors understand the gesture must have some unknown, possibly derogatory, meaning here, and wisely decide to retreat to the ship before committing another faux pas.

<b>The man smiles, and a conversation slowly begins,</b> accompanied by a smattering of local idioms and considerable use of sign language. You dash forward, but inhale some of the chalky dust stirred by the fall of the rubble. <b>You wisely turn back</b> as increasingly larger fragments of painted stone start tumbling from the ceiling with shattering cracks. When you reach the previous room it becomes evident that most of the path ahead has caved in. Not desiring to return to ship just yet, you cautiously make for the second staircase you had noticed. A short descent brings you to what must have once been a chamber. You take a few tentative steps across the antique tiles, an aching worry stabbing at your heart— and rightly so, for you are only a few steps in when a series of adjacent tiles shatter audibly below you. You feel your feet swept away as <b>a gaping pit rushes up to swallow you.</b>

You lurch forward and grab one of the edges, pulling yourself up and out of immediate peril with a final leap towards the end of the room. As the tremors ebb away and the dust settles you look around. <b>A narrow stairwell leads down into the dark to the east, while an uneven set of steps heads down to wide passage to the west.</b> The depths grumble and growl eerily.

You leap for the edge but your hand closes on a sharp piece of debris. You cry out in pain— too late. The abyss rises up to meet you. Harsh dust clings to your eyelids, and burns your eyes as you plummet to the floor, where with a tremendous crack, you feel your bones shatter  and the darkness takes you. Your companions will doubtless <b>raise their black sails in solemn remembrance before journeying on without you.</b>

<b>You brace for impact,</b> knees bent and body supple, preparing to break your fall the way other riggers taught you when you first joined the ship. Blistering pain surges through your ankle, but you're confident it is sprained, and not broken. You scramble to hold on to something, but everything is giving way around you. You scream helplessly, to no avail— you are far too deep below the bleached hillsides, and far too removed from your fellow crew members. You grab a jutting rock, but it gives way. <font size='36'>There is still much talk of the sailor lass and the thyme-scented island. Where next?</font>

<b>You are alone, seeking the fabled Lost Necropolis.</b> Fables that seem just about credible when eyeing the pale golden shimmer of windswept dusk from the seat of your camel. Somewhere out there in these wastes, beyond cyclopean basalt pillars, may lie the hoard of kings of old— and its greatest prize, the Vigil of Hor, a statue said to be made from the purest gold and inlaid with countless gems. Your stopover is a busy city on the delta not far from the supposed site of the tombs. A young woman with an academic demeanour hails you as you cross paths in the national museum. "I have found something," she says, "and seek a responsible person to <b>help the local museum recover it."</b>

You recognize the insignia of the prestigious House of Sands university on the young woman's lapel— <b>an erudite, no doubt.</b> Explaining at great length that she cares little for riches and only wishes to see the history of her people returned to this museum, she lays a ragged, age-tarnished map on the low delicate table in a musty back office. Strange symbols abound all over it, etched over crisscrossing lines all leading up to a city facing a jackal's head.<br/>'Assiout, as mentioned in the Book of the Dead. And here: "Follow the Opener-of-Paths, Anubis <custom-entity tag="jackal_128px_dark"/>, the divine embalmer, who holds the key to Assiout." <b>We need only find where the trail begins!'</b>

<b>It is four days' peaceful ride from the city to the ruined temple of Anubis,</b> further inland. Dark colonnades and intricate carvings half-buried tower silently over you, before you climb a set of elephantine stairs leading to a colossal figure. It's head that of a  jackal, unsettling light glimmering in its deep red-gemmed eyes.<br/> As you bow in deference before the long-dead god, you notice a pale serpent slither from a crack in the wall beyond. Intrigued, you poke and pry at stone blocks, until with a sedimented rumble, they give way!  <b>A secret cavity</b> beyond hides many animal-headed jars, bedecked with tarnished riches and scrawling glyphs etched across the walls.

<b>'This... this is the Book of the Dead!</b> All of it— all 192 spells and incantations!' The young historian is ecstatic; evidently this is an unprecedented discovery. 'And see here... yes it is near-complete! It reads "Follow the Opener-of-Paths, Anubis <custom-entity tag="jackal_128px_dark"/>, the divine embalmer, embark through the ocean-of-million-years, where no life is allowed <custom-entity tag="water_128px_dark"/>, and when the divine star rises from dark waters <custom-entity tag="sunnny_128px_dark"/>the City of the Dead will unveil itself." She starts scribbling furiously in her notebooks, copying signs and sketching vases, as <b>you ponder this new enigma.</b>

<b>Never mind the scorching days and long chill nights</b>, as you follow Anubis's red gaze to a small ledge beneath a mountain summit.<br/>As camp breaks for a new day into the unknown, you turn to the pale horizon and send up a hesitant prayer. To what, you are unsure, but Something answers.<br/>Tall silhouettes flare out of nothingness, delineated by the fragile husky light of dawn: The Lost Necropolis! Scattered with duskclad pillars and strange pyramids, and arches spanning fathomless chasms of darkness.<br/>At the centre of it all, casting a pale-green pall over the silent city, stands a mausoleum of godly proportions. Atop the grim entrance, <b>ominous signs are carved.</b>

<b>The delight in her eyes at the wonder around her soon fades</b> into a darker, fearful mood as she traces the glyphs with her fingers, her lips breathlessly shaping the arcane sounds within.<br/>'Here rests Osiris Ounénnefer, by the care of watchful Anubis, until forever is no more and vengeance falls upon his foes. Within lies judgment, without oblivion and all are his dominion. Come to him with a true heart and <b>join in the secret feasts of the Duat.'</b>

<b>A long passage slopes down into the earth.</b> Ornate paintings must once have covered every inch of the walls, but now only indecipherable lines and constellations survive from what must have been a wondrously complex depiction of the night sky. 'Nout, the dusk-winged;' whispers the young scholar, reverently. A narrow chamber, empty but for a few scuttling black beetles. The paintings here are in a far greater state of conservation: human bodies with monstrous animal heads, cosmically vast landscapes and pagan offerings.<br/><b>Two lower passages head east and west into the darkness,</b> below arches covered in symbols.

She was just ahead of you, but all of a sudden <b>the Scholar has vanished!</b> Perhaps something awful befell her, or perhaps...<b>this is indeed the correct path,</b> and she no longer has a use for you. Ahead is a low-ceilinged hall surrounded by ornate dusky pillars. A sealed door, unadorned and heavy, is carved into the opposing wall. All around it stretches a masterfully painted scene: a set of giant scales, one bearing up a beating heart, the other a feather. Anthropomorphic beasts take careful note of the proceedings while a ghastly, fiendish monster snaps at the heels of a line of terrified figures. As you look around, a strange and distant howling startles you. <b>A hidden door is very slightly ajar,</b> betrayed by the wind blowing over its threshold.

<b>A long silence fills the chamber as your torch softly sputters out.</b> Darkness, then— the sound of softly lapping water near your feet. Something— several Somethings— weave silkily between your toes, unseen colossi stalking, sensing...<br/>You mutter in breathless prayer. Perhaps your humility, perhaps your calm, seems to have had a positive effect. As uncannily as it came, the water seeps away, taking the strange entities with it. <b>The path ahead is clear.</b>

Not daring to touch the door, <b>you slip through the crack.</b> The new chamber is colossal, tall enough to welcome a temple. Long stone grooves trace the sides, filled with mummified animals and multitudinous basins brimming with pale gold and jewelry. But despite the splendour you have eyes for but one thing: a pyramid of black stone, carved with a set of steep stairs and bearing a chalk-white crown. Atop the pyramid, on an altar of midnight amber, <b>stands the fabled Statue of Hor—</b>He of the Thousand Thrones, Commiserer of the Penitent and Humble and Purger of the Unworthy— <b>there, for the taking!</b>

<b>Perhaps Anubis deems you worthy.</b> Perhaps he slumbers until Forever sunders, or perhaps...he has seen the truth of your heart.<br/>The statue is weighty but easily removed from its pedestal. Uneasy at the silence and gloom, you make a hasty retreat out the chamber, half-convinced that something stirs in the deep chasms all around. As you pull the Door of Judgement precautiously shut you notice a wan, lifeless face, shining out from the darkness beyond— the young scholar! Something is closing upon her, like the night, claiming her for itself.<br/><br/>Despite this last and grizzly vision, you yourself are free of the tomb. And what's this? The Effigy of Hor in your hands!

<b>You decide to leave the pyramid untouched</b> but take what other riches you can from the chamber. Gold, silver, gems and jewelry of the most exquisite craftsmanship are shoved into pockets— a treasure-trove of kingly proportions!<br/>As you make a difficult way back to the sands far above, you notice a pale, unblinking face in one of the deep trenches: the young historian. You make to recover her body, but something— a darkness— slithers over her, and she is gone.<br/>You find yourself strangely relieved to have left the statue alone. The tale is wondrous enough for twenty fireside already— and who knows? <b>Perhaps one day you will walk the streets of the Necropolis again...</b>

You hold your pistol at the ready, <b>and cross the threshold quietly.</b> Water laps at your feet, distant bubbling— crocodiles, you suspect. How do they survive down here? They move towards you.<br/>A crackle of shots followed by the warm smell of blood welling into the water. A moment's silence, then a prudent match briefly lights the floating corpses of two colossal beasts— crocodiles of unholy proportions, their scales pale as bone. The crimsoning waters reassure you however: <b>if it bleeds, it can be slain.</b>

A high chamber stretches into the darkness around a basalt pyramid. At the pyramid's bone-white crown is a pedestal, bearing the fabled Statue of Hor. <b>Standing before it is the historian.</b> She seems entranced, her fingers inches from the exquisite golden limbs. Her mutterings echo strangely, 'At last, they will know... Such opportunities... Never want for anything again...' Something draws your attention at the foot of the pyramid; slithering there, a patch of unquiet, restless darkness.<br/><b>The historian's hand reaches out towards the statue.</b>

<b>You bound stupidly towards her,</b> crying for her to beware, but billowing tendrils of mist wrap around her, dark many-coloured fumes spew from deep grooves around the pyramid's base. You plunge forward through the mists. It is like sand, like minuscule shards of glass tearing at you. A scream fills the chamber, inhuman and terrified— yours, hers, or something else. Rumbling shakes the ground. A chorus of ear-shattering whispers peels at your skin. Something in you breaks. Dissolves. Your eyes burn with a blazing white halo— a silhouette, great wings. The promise of wrath. <br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>Grim whispers echo strangely from the shadowy confines of the chamber.</b> A swirling, cloying sensation almost knocks you over as Something wakes. The historian's mutterings grow louder, deafeningly louder, painfully louder. A resounding crack, as of bones shattered.<br/>Then silence.<br/><br/>When your eyes open the chamber is empty. The light from your torches flickers dully on the statue. Sand, great pyramidia of bleak sand, piles high against the chamber walls. The historian is nowhere to be seen. Deciding it best not to linger, you wrap the statue carefully and respectfully <b>before retreating gleefully out of the necropolis.</b>

<b>A trap!</b> No sooner had you crossed the threshold than the door groaned shut, sprung by some age-old mechanism under your step. You pummel against it, but in vain. The path ahead leads to a minuscule chamber, barely tall enough for you to stand in. Slits in the walls point to where air vents must have been, now utterly sealed. The place reeks of a husky, brittle air.<br/>You start to feel light-headed— surely the air hasn't already run out? Figures on the walls appear to dance eerily in the torchlight. Suddenly your torch flares out. You rasp for breath then— <b>darkness, and the silence of the Necropolis.</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>There are powers beyond the reckoning even of the wise.</b> Who knows what lies in the sandswept valley and tomb? Better let the Lord of the Dead rest unperturbed.<br/>As you make a troubled way back up the mountain, a hawk swoops mere feet over your shoulder, startling you. As it springs back up, a dark speck against the morning sun, you spy something in the sands by your feet: <b>a cluster of tablets, joined with ancient reeds, covered in script— a priceless treasure in its own right.</b> A gift perhaps? Or a token of gratitude? Who knows what mysteries slumber, no more than half-dead, beneath the sands of this strange land.

As soon as <b>Polaris is seen shimmering in the sky</b> you head off into the desert cold. The historian smilingly bids you farewell and disappears into the slow bustle of the market.<br/>Far above, golden-red in the light of a new day, a hawk drops to a quiet roost atop the pyramid's alabaster peak.

A glance is enough for the historian to tell you <b>this alcove was a preparation room used in the mummification process;</b> she warns you not to open the sealed jars, for your own sake. The historian points to a series of symbols: 'Here, the "way of the king's jackal"'.<br/>It seems to be a procession: first a mummy interred, then dawn offerings on a mountaintop, a journey of some sort with the mummy in an oddly shaped sarcophagus— then a ritual of mummification?

At second glance it seems obvious this text must be deciphered dextrosinistrally. It details a journey, perhaps not as metaphorical as you might have thought.<br/>The opportunity is too great to miss: you order camels saddled and prepare to ride across the desert.<br/> Several days' journey brings you to a high mountaintop.<br/>As camp breaks for a new day, suddenly tall silhouettes flare out of nothingness, delineated by the fragile husky light of dawn: a vast necropolis, scattered with duskclad pillars and strange pyramids.<br/>At the centre of it all stands a mausoleum of godly proportions. Atop the grim entrance, <b>ominous signs are carved.</b>

<b>A grave mistake.</b> Taking one of the jars seems to have activated a hidden mechanism! You leap out just in time— a heavy slab of sand-gold stone slams down onto the tiles where only a second ago was your ankle.<br/>Doused by this unfortunate brush with a gruesome fate, <b>you decide it is best to leave this place and its secrets to the desert.</b> Some tales are best forgotten, and besides: who ever would believe you?

There is <b>something strange about the way the jars are slightly out of order</b>; best not to disturb anything. There are plenty of other riches scattered across the small chamber, bracelets and rings and diadems and more. Plenty enough to ensure a triumphant return back to ship. <b>The ruins of Assiout are barely visible</b> underneath a shroud of sand and thorn-riddled shrubs. After two days covering your faces from the scorching winds, you have come upon a tall statue; probably one of the local divinities. It is unmarred by time nor wind, and eerily lifelike. A sudden growl, low and threatening, seemingly disembodied. Surely not the statue...? As you contemplate retreating from these weird grounds, you sense movement behind the statue. <b>Three black-gold jackals step noiselessly from its shadow,</b> shaking sand off their shoulders. Unnerved by their ghostly footfall, you turn to the statue; you could swear it is glaring down at you in judgement.

<b>She is visibly terrified,</b> and resorts to desperation. Stooping to pick up a fragment of the statue's broken pedestal, she hurls it at the brutes before pelting off into the ruins! One of the jackals yelps in pain as the rock strikes it's foreleg and the trio of dogs give chase to the unfortunate girl. <b>You will never know what becomes of her.</b> As soon as they have left you sneak out like a coward and examine the place where the creatures appeared. After some excavating, your efforts uncover a crack in the tiles of a sand-clad set of stairs. A small cavity below hides many animal-headed jars, bedecked with tarnished riches and <b>scrawling glyphs etched across the walls.</b>

<b>A quick, dextrous shot cripples one of the beasts' legs from under it,</b> and its allies flee squealing. A further blow with the butt of your rifle saves the wounded animal further suffering. Searching nearby, you note scuffs in the dust at the base of one of the columns as if it has been moved. You give it a gentle push and sure enough it swings apart on a hinge, revealing a set of stone stairs in the floor.<br/>You investigate the obscure cavity below. Narrow beams of sunlight from above touch many animal-headed jars, bedecked with tarnished riches and <b>scrawling glyphs etched across the walls.</b>

<b>You steady your rifle to take a shot</b> but one of the brutes leaps at your arm, latching on with immense strength, while its companion bounds up and down on the spot, cackling maniacally. You attempt to push the beast off but the weight of it sends you toppling to the floor.<br/>The last thing you see is the creature's strangely calm face, gazing at the statue, as though its kill were some manner of offering...Your mind and vision race. Red eyes bleed gemstones in their thousands. A great feather held in a hand of shadow tickles you beyond suffering.</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

Careful observation from your sideways glances has left you <b>a decent impression of the temple's structure.</b> Hurtling a pebble at the lead dog, you leap over a nearby wall, pelting through the roofless colonnade beyond with the creatures hot on your heels. You feel a set of fangs snap at thin air mere inches from your calf as you reach for a ledge and effortlessly swing over it.<br/>Suddenly the howling and yelping stops. After a short time you survey the ruin. No sign of the creatures, but the thought they may reappear plagues your investigations. <b>You give up on finding the Lost Necropolis and return to sea to rejoin your crew.</b> You hesitate, but decide it better to not let them know the strange names and words you believe you heard beneath the jackals' cries.

<b>A fool's hope.</b> The beasts know every passage, every shadow, every secret of the sands. You weave through the temple ruin as best you can, but the jackals ignore every attempt to mislead them. You are cornered— a nook between two closed rooms, with no visible egress.<br/>You lunge at one of the canines but it hops aside, its manic laughter ringing insultingly in your ears, then latches onto your upper arm. Its companions bounce into you, sending you sprawling, and <b>close their fuming maws on your throat. Mind and vision race. Red eyes bleed gemstones in their thousands. A great feather held in a hand of shadow tickles you beyond suffering.</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>Hardly a challenge for a seasoned navigator.</b> The trail points to an oasis at a crossroads of two mountainous hinterlands where, myth has it, one of the entrances to the underworld lies, below the water.<br/>Dark orange cliffs cast a soothing shadow over the oasis to the joyous din of travelling merchants, wanderers and treasure-seekers. You look up to a high cliff and can't help but wonder where such a death-defying leap into the water would take you.

<b>You nimbly climb the burning rock.</b> There is a moment's tantalised breathing as you step to the edge of the cliff— then air rushes around you as you fall.<br/>You zip into the cerulean waters with barely a splash, fearlessly avoiding a series of cruel spurs jutting from the shallows. As you open your eyes a strong current drags you through a series of algae-clad passages, before weird lights incite you to push upwards to an airhole. <b>Your faith is rewarded.</b> A shallow chamber, painted with a once beautiful depiction— a reed raft birthing the sun out of rippling waters, and into the star-dotted sky. <b>Two dark passageways lead further into the stone.</b>

She spits water from her mouth, and clears her nose. <b>Her usually quiet demeanour is overcome by passion</b> as she examines the painting. 'They say the raft holding the sun was to forever travel between the lands of the living and those of the dead. See? Here the raft emerges triumphant from the matricial waters. And there darkness takes it, and the journey underground begins. Do you see? Land of the Dead, Necropolis... they are one and the same! <b>We must follow the Journey as was ordained: westward, into evening!'</b>

<b>Interminable galleries wind across and over each other,</b> spanning fathomless pits on spindly natural bridges. Hours you walk, with no sign of relief until— light! You scramble and dig, extricating yourselves until you come to stand on a small ledge above an incredible sight: a vast necropolis, scattered with duskclad pillars and strange pyramids, cyclopean arches spanning fathomless chasms of darkness.<br/>At the centre of it all, casting a shadowy pall over the city, stands a mausoleum of godly proportions. Atop the grim entrance, <b>ominous signs are carved.</b>

After some fumbling in the dark <b>the passage starts to slope upwards.</b> It is some time however before you come to a thin crack in the wall. You tear eagerly at the crevice, feeling it crumble easily under your hands. As you slip out an ominous rumble echoes through the passage as it collapses behind you. <b>Trapped!</b> Before you, the quietly frothing waters of a hidden fountain, kept from all human eyes for millenia, welcome you. Perhaps this is what the legends truly meant— life in the most improbable of places? You fade slowly...</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>The ascent is steeper than you had anticipated,</b> and the sheer drop inreasingly intimidating. You stare down at the waters and a strange faintness comes into your heart. Breath deserts you, trembling seizes your limbs. The rocks surrounding the basin, far, far below, seem jagged and cruel, and you could almost thear them calling to you, yearning for a taste of your flesh, of your marrow.<br/>Some time later you find yourself struggling back down the cliffside. When you have drunk from the waters, you feel tired, and <b>decide it probably best if you rejoin the rest of the expedition.</b>

<b>You turn regretfully from the shimmering waters</b> and journey back to reconvene with the rest of the expedition.They feel none of your disappointment in not having found the Lost Necropolis, and it does not marr their enthusiasm in hearing of the wonders and beauties of your journey, however fruitless it may have been.

<b>The task is more arduous than it seems.</b> After much befuddlement you manage to find a point of convergence somewhere in the distant desert hinterlands. Gathering supplies, you hastily head into the desert, braving the scorching heat and dismally chilly nights in your quest for long-lost reward.<br/>As you head further into the dunes however, you are swiftly sobered by the realization that you may already be hopelessly and irretrievably lost, for <b>how to tell one dune from another in an endless sea of sand?</b>

<b>No hope but to trust the instinct of the king of the desert.</b> Hopefully the camel will know the way to some nearby oasis. If not...<br/>As soon as the beast's bridle is unlatched it darts across the sand, vanishing beyond cresting dunes at a steady amble while you rush to follow.<br/>Fortune favours you! After some running and considerable cursing, you come to the bustling oasis of Awis, a waterspring tucked at a crossroads of dark crimson mountains. Legend claims the waters hide a gateway the Lands of the Dead. <b>Perhaps hope is not entirely forlorn yet!</b> It would only take a short climb, then a long, steep dive...

<b>The land is harsh and unforgiving.</b> There is little shade to be found during the day, when the searing rays of the sun glare down disapprovingly on you. What shade there is turns out not to be safe. Exhausted, you fall asleep under an overhanging rock, only to wake at a sharp pain in your neck— two telltale puncture holes. The young historian is nowhere to be found. You wonder if the Lord of Sands will have mercy on you— it seems unlikely— He is not known for being merciful.<br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>The venom of an asp has taken you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>The desert sky at night has a soothing, calming quality.</b> Though the stars are strange and foreign, and many familiar constellations are disconcertingly twisted, you chart a rough cartography of the skies to correspond to the desert before you.<br/>It is just a few days before you come again to the desert's edge, into lands where thirst can easily by quenched and rest had for a nominal fee, yet <b>it will be with no small pride</b> that you will recount your strange experience among the dunes to the rest of the expedition.

<b>The stars are strange and contrary.</b> Familiar landmarks of the heavens seem oddly missing, as you scan the night for anything sympathetic. Something does not wish you to find a way out of the desert. You steel forward to the best of your ability, charting vague patterns and routes across increasingly desiccated paper, but every passing day drives you closer to death and insanity. Perhaps a cautionary tale will be told of your and the young archaeologists' disappearance.<br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>Her scepticism shows plainly on her face.</b> Grave robbers are found often in these lands, and doubtless she counts you among their number.
