<b>You are alone, seeking the fabled Lost Necropolis.</b> Fables that seem just about credible when eyeing the pale golden shimmer of windswept dusk from the seat of your camel. Somewhere out there in these wastes, beyond cyclopean basalt pillars, may lie the hoard of kings of old— and its greatest prize, the Vigil of Hor, a statue said to be made from the purest gold and inlaid with countless gems. Your stopover is a busy city on the delta not far from the supposed site of the tombs. A young woman with an academic demeanour hails you as you cross paths in the national museum. "I have found something," she says, "and seek a responsible person to <b>help the local museum recover it."</b>

You recognize the insignia of the prestigious House of Sands university on the young woman's lapel— <b>an erudite, no doubt.</b> Explaining at great length that she cares little for riches and only wishes to see the history of her people returned to this museum, she lays a ragged, age-tarnished map on the low delicate table in a musty back office. Strange symbols abound all over it, etched over crisscrossing lines all leading up to a city facing a jackal's head.<br/>'Assiout, as mentioned in the Book of the Dead. And here: "Follow the Opener-of-Paths, Anubis <custom-entity tag="jackal_128px_dark"/>, the divine embalmer, who holds the key to Assiout." <b>We need only find where the trail begins!'</b>

<b>It is four days' peaceful ride from the city to the ruined temple of Anubis,</b> further inland. Dark colonnades and intricate carvings half-buried tower silently over you, before you climb a set of elephantine stairs leading to a colossal figure. It's head that of a  jackal, unsettling light glimmering in its deep red-gemmed eyes.<br/> As you bow in deference before the long-dead god, you notice a pale serpent slither from a crack in the wall beyond. Intrigued, you poke and pry at stone blocks, until with a sedimented rumble, they give way!  <b>A secret cavity</b> beyond hides many animal-headed jars, bedecked with tarnished riches and scrawling glyphs etched across the walls.

<b>'This... this is the Book of the Dead!</b> All of it— all 192 spells and incantations!' The young historian is ecstatic; evidently this is an unprecedented discovery. 'And see here... yes it is near-complete! It reads "Follow the Opener-of-Paths, Anubis <custom-entity tag="jackal_128px_dark"/>, the divine embalmer, embark through the ocean-of-million-years, where no life is allowed <custom-entity tag="water_128px_dark"/>, and when the divine star rises from dark waters <custom-entity tag="sunnny_128px_dark"/>the City of the Dead will unveil itself." She starts scribbling furiously in her notebooks, copying signs and sketching vases, as <b>you ponder this new enigma.</b>

<b>Never mind the scorching days and long chill nights</b>, as you follow Anubis's red gaze to a small ledge beneath a mountain summit.<br/>As camp breaks for a new day into the unknown, you turn to the pale horizon and send up a hesitant prayer. To what, you are unsure, but Something answers.<br/>Tall silhouettes flare out of nothingness, delineated by the fragile husky light of dawn: The Lost Necropolis! Scattered with duskclad pillars and strange pyramids, and arches spanning fathomless chasms of darkness.<br/>At the center of it all, casting a pale-green pall over the silent city, stands a mausoleum of godly proportions. Atop the grim entrance, <b>ominous signs are carved.</b>

<b>The delight in her eyes at the wonder around her soon fades</b> into a darker, fearful mood as she traces the glyphs with her fingers, her lips breathlessly shaping the arcane sounds within.<br/>'Here rests Osiris Ounénnefer, by the care of watchful Anubis, until forever is no more and vengeance falls upon his foes. Within lies judgment, without oblivion and all are his dominion. Come to him with a true heart and <b>join in the secret feasts of the Duat.'</b>

<b>A long passage slopes down into the earth.</b> Ornate paintings must once have covered every inch of the walls, but now only indecipherable lines and constellations survive from what must have been a wondrously complex depiction of the night sky. 'Nout, the dusk-winged;' whispers the young scholar, reverently. A narrow chamber, empty but for a few scuttling black beetles. The paintings here are in a far greater state of conservation: human bodies with monstrous animal heads, cosmically vast landscapes and pagan offerings.<br/><b>Two lower passages head east and west into the darkness,</b> below arches covered in symbols.

She was just ahead of you, but all of a sudden <b>the Scholar has vanished!</b> Perhaps something awful befell her, or perhaps...<b>this is indeed the correct path,</b> and she no longer has a use for you. Ahead is a low-ceilinged hall surrounded by ornate dusky pillars. A sealed door, unadorned and heavy, is carved into the opposing wall. All around it stretches a masterfully painted scene: a set of giant scales, one bearing up a beating heart, the other a feather. Anthropomorphic beasts take careful note of the proceedings while a ghastly, fiendish monster snaps at the heels of a line of terrified figures. As you look around, a strange and distant howling startles you. <b>A hidden door is very slightly ajar,</b> betrayed by the wind blowing over its threshold.

<b>A long silence fills the chamber as your torch softly sputters out.</b> Darkness, then— the sound of softly lapping water near your feet. Something— several Somethings— weave silkily between your toes, unseen colossi stalking, sensing...<br/>You mutter in breathless prayer. Perhaps your humility, perhaps your calm, seems to have had a positive effect. As uncannily as it came, the water seeps away, taking the strange entities with it. <b>The path ahead is clear.</b>

Not daring to touch the door, <b>you slip through the crack.</b> The new chamber is colossal, tall enough to welcome a temple. Long stone grooves trace the sides, filled with mummified animals and multitudinous basins brimming with pale gold and jewelry. But despite the splendour you have eyes for but one thing: a pyramid of black stone, carved with a set of steep stairs and bearing a chalk-white crown. Atop the pyramid, on an altar of midnight amber, <b>stands the fabled Statue of Hor—</b>He of the Thousand Thrones, Commiserer of the Penitent and Humble and Purger of the Unworthy— <b>there, for the taking!</b>

<b>Perhaps Anubis deems you worthy.</b> Perhaps he slumbers until Forever sunders, or perhaps...he has seen the truth of your heart.<br/>The statue is weighty but easily removed from its pedestal. Uneasy at the silence and gloom, you make a hasty retreat out the chamber, half-convinced that something stirs in the deep chasms all around. As you pull the Door of Judgement precautiously shut you notice a wan, lifeless face, shining out from the darkness beyond— the young scholar! Something is closing upon her, like the night, claiming her for itself.<br/><br/>Despite this last and grizzly vision, you yourself are free of the tomb. And what's this? The Effigy of Hor in your hands!

<b>You decide to leave the pyramid untouched</b> but take what other riches you can from the chamber. Gold, silver, gems and jewelry of the most exquisite craftsmanship are shoved into pockets— a treasure-trove of kingly proportions!<br/>As you make a difficult way back to the sands far above, you notice a pale, unblinking face in one of the deep trenches: the young historian. You make to recover her body, but something— a darkness— slithers over her, and she is gone.<br/>You find yourself strangely relieved to have left the statue alone. The tale is wondrous enough for twenty fireside already— and who knows? <b>Perhaps one day you will walk the streets of the Necropolis again...</b>

You hold your pistol at the ready, <b>and cross the threshold quietly.</b> Water laps at your feet, distant bubbling— crocodiles, you suspect. How do they survive down here? They move towards you.<br/>A crackle of shots followed by the warm smell of blood welling into the water. A moment's silence, then a prudent match briefly lights the floating corpses of two colossal beasts— crocodiles of unholy proportions, their scales pale as bone. The crimsoning waters reassure you however: <b>if it bleeds, it can be slain.</b>

A high chamber stretches into the darkness around a basalt pyramid. At the pyramid's bone-white crown is a pedestal, bearing the fabled Statue of Hor. <b>Standing before it is the historian.</b> She seems entranced, her fingers inches from the exquisite golden limbs. Her mutterings echo strangely, 'At last, they will know... Such opportunities... Never want for anything again...' Something draws your attention at the foot of the pyramid; slithering there, a patch of unquiet, restless darkness.<br/><b>The historian's hand reaches out towards the statue.</b>

<b>You bound stupidly towards her,</b> crying for her to beware, but billowing tendrils of mist wrap around her, dark many-coloured fumes spew from deep grooves around the pyramid's base. You plunge forward through the mists. It is like sand, like minuscule shards of glass tearing at you. A scream fills the chamber, inhuman and terrified— yours, hers, or something else. Rumbling shakes the ground. A chorus of ear-shattering whispers peels at your skin. Something in you breaks. Dissolves. Your eyes burn with a blazing white halo— a silhouette, great wings. The promise of wrath. <br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>Grim whispers echo strangely from the shadowy confines of the chamber.</b> A swirling, cloying sensation almost knocks you over as Something wakes. The historian's mutterings grow louder, deafeningly louder, painfully louder. A resounding crack, as of bones shattered.<br/>Then silence.<br/><br/>When your eyes open the chamber is empty. The light from your torches flickers dully on the statue. Sand, great pyramidia of bleak sand, piles high against the chamber walls. The historian is nowhere to be seen. Deciding it best not to linger, you wrap the statue carefully and respectfully <b>before retreating gleefully out of the necropolis.</b>

<b>A trap!</b> No sooner had you crossed the threshold than the door groaned shut, sprung by some age-old mechanism under your step. You pummel against it, but in vain. The path ahead leads to a minuscule chamber, barely tall enough for you to stand in. Slits in the walls point to where air vents must have been, now utterly sealed. The place reeks of a husky, brittle air.<br/>You start to feel light-headed— surely the air hasn't already run out? Figures on the walls appear to dance eerily in the torchlight. Suddenly your torch flares out. You rasp for breath then— <b>darkness, and the silence of the Necropolis.</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>There are powers beyond the reckoning even of the wise.</b> Who knows what lies in the sandswept valley and tomb? Better let the Lord of the Dead rest unperturbed.<br/>As you make a troubled way back up the mountain, a hawk swoops mere feet over your shoulder, startling you. As it springs back up, a dark speck against the morning sun, you spy something in the sands by your feet: <b>a cluster of tablets, joined with ancient reeds, covered in script— a priceless treasure in its own right.</b> A gift perhaps? Or a token of gratitude? Who knows what mysteries slumber, no more than half-dead, beneath the sands of this strange land.

As soon as <b>Polaris is seen shimmering in the sky</b> you head off into the desert cold. Sleep settles in despite your efforts, and you doze offas your camel paces unerringly forward in the night.<br/>Morning greets you with a glorious sight: a pyramid, sun-tanned and immense, blazing with aurorean light on the horizon! Four millenia, perhaps more, standing a quiet vigil over communities and travelers untouched by time. Even the sands seem to hold still. You may not have found the Lost Necropolis, but you are safe. The historian smilingly bids you farewell and disappears into the slow bustle of the market.<br/>Far above, golden-red in the light of a new day, a hawk drops to a quiet roost atop the pyramid's alabaster peak.

A glance is enough for the historian to tell you <b>this alcove was a preparation room used in the mummification process;</b> she warns you not to open the sealed jars, for your own sake. Beneath a mixture of dust and sand you find a scroll— <b>a papyrus, relatively intact despite its age.</b> You unroll it gingerly, finding it to be several feet long and covered with countless figures and signs. The historian points to a series of symbols: 'Here, the "way of the king's jackal"'.<br/>It seems to be a procession: first a mummy interred, then dawn offerings on a mountaintop, a journey of some sort with the mummy in an oddly shaped sarcophagus— then a ritual of mummification?

At second glance it seems obvious this text must be deciphered dextrosinistrally. It details a journey, perhaps not as metaphorical as you might have thought.<br/>The opportunity is too great to miss: you order camels saddled and prepare to ride across the desert.<br/> Several days' journey brings you to a high mountaintop.<br/>As camp breaks for a new day, suddenly tall silhouettes flare out of nothingness, delineated by the fragile husky light of dawn: a vast necropolis, scattered with duskclad pillars and strange pyramids.<br/>At the center of it all stands a mausoleum of godly proportions. Atop the grim entrance, <b>ominous signs are carved.</b>

<b>A grave mistake.</b> Taking one of the jars seems to have activated a hidden mechanism! You leap out just in time— a heavy slab of sand-gold stone slams down onto the tiles where only a second ago was your ankle.<br/>Doused by this unfortunate brush with a gruesome fate, <b>you decide it is best to leave this place and its secrets to the desert.</b> Some tales are best forgotten, and besides: who ever would believe you?

There is <b>something strange about the way the jars are slightly out of order</b>; best not to disturb anything. There are plenty of other riches scattered across the small chamber, bracelets and rings and diadems and more. Plenty enough to ensure a triumphant return back to ship. Even such trinkets will be sure to draw much wonder and praise!

<b>The ruins of Assiout are barely visible</b> underneath a shroud of sand and thorn-riddled shrubs. After two days covering your faces from the scorching winds, you have come upon a tall statue; probably one of the local divinities. It is unmarred by time nor wind, and eerily lifelike. A sudden growl, low and threatening, seemingly disembodied. Surely not the statue...? As you contemplate retreating from these weird grounds, you sense movement behind the statue. <b>Three black-gold jackals step noiselessly from its shadow,</b> shaking sand off their shoulders. Unnerved by their ghostly footfall, you turn to the statue; you could swear it is glaring down at you in judgement.

<b>She is visibly terrified,</b> and resorts to desperation. Stooping to pick up a fragment of the statue's broken pedestal, she hurls it at the brutes before pelting off into the ruins! One of the jackals yelps in pain as the rock strikes it's foreleg and the trio of dogs give chase to the unfortunate girl. <b>You will never know what becomes of her.</b> As soon as they have left you sneak out like a coward and examine the place where the creatures appeared. After some excavating, your efforts uncover a crack in the tiles of a sand-clad set of stairs. A small cavity below hides many animal-headed jars, bedecked with tarnished riches and <b>scrawling glyphs etched across the walls.</b>

<b>A quick, dextrous shot cripples one of the beasts' legs from under it,</b> and its allies flee squealing. A further blow with the butt of your rifle saves the wounded animal further suffering. Searching nearby, you note scuffs in the dust at the base of one of the columns as if it has been moved. You give it a gentle push and sure enough it swings apart on a hinge, revealing a set of stone stairs in the floor.<br/>You investigate the obscure cavity below. Narrow beams of sunlight from above touch many animal-headed jars, bedecked with tarnished riches and <b>scrawling glyphs etched across the walls.</b>

<b>You steady your rifle to take a shot</b> but one of the brutes leaps at your arm, latching on with immense strength, while its companion bounds up and down on the spot, cackling maniacally. You attempt to push the beast off but the weight of it sends you toppling to the floor.<br/>The last thing you see is the creature's strangely calm face, gazing at the statue, as though its kill were some manner of offering...Your mind and vision race. Red eyes bleed gemstones in their thousands. A great feather held in a hand of shadow tickles you beyond suffering.</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

Careful observation from your sideways glances has left you <b>a decent impression of the temple's structure.</b> Hurtling a pebble at the lead dog, you leap over a nearby wall, pelting through the roofless colonnade beyond with the creatures hot on your heels. You feel a set of fangs snap at thin air mere inches from your calf as you reach for a ledge and effortlessly swing over it.<br/>Suddenly the howling and yelping stops. After a short time you survey the ruin. No sign of the creatures, but the thought they may reappear plagues your investigations. <b>You give up on finding the Lost Necropolis and return to sea to rejoin your crew.</b> You hesitate, but decide it better to not let them know the strange names and words you believe you heard beneath the jackals' cries.

<b>A fool's hope.</b> The beasts know every passage, every shadow, every secret of the sands. You weave through the temple ruin as best you can, but the jackals ignore every attempt to mislead them. You are cornered— a nook between two closed rooms, with no visible egress.<br/>You lunge at one of the canines but it hops aside, its manic laughter ringing insultingly in your ears, then latches onto your upper arm. Its companions bounce into you, sending you sprawling, and <b>close their fuming maws on your throat. Mind and vision race. Red eyes bleed gemstones in their thousands. A great feather held in a hand of shadow tickles you beyond suffering.</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>Hardly a challenge for a seasoned navigator.</b> The trail points to an oasis at a crossroads of two mountainous hinterlands where, myth has it, one of the entrances to the underworld lies, below the water.<br/>Dark orange cliffs cast a soothing shadow over the oasis to the joyous din of travelling merchants, wanderers and treasure-seekers. You look up to a high cliff and can't help but wonder where such a death-defying leap into the water would take you.

<b>You nimbly climb the burning rock.</b> There is a moment's tantalised breathing as you step to the edge of the cliff— then air rushes around you as you fall.<br/>You zip into the cerulean waters with barely a splash, fearlessly avoiding a series of cruel spurs jutting from the shallows. As you open your eyes a strong current drags you through a series of algae-clad passages, before weird lights incite you to push upwards to an airhole. <b>Your faith is rewarded.</b> A shallow chamber, painted with a once beautiful depiction— a reed raft birthing the sun out of rippling waters, and into the star-dotted sky. <b>Two dark passageways lead further into the stone.</b>

She spits water from her mouth, and clears her nose. <b>Her usually quiet demeanour is overcome by passion</b> as she examines the painting. 'They say the raft holding the sun was to forever travel between the lands of the living and those of the dead. See? Here the raft emerges triumphant from the matricial waters. And there darkness takes it, and the journey underground begins. Do you see? Land of the Dead, Necropolis... they are one and the same! <b>We must follow the Journey as was ordained: westward, into evening!'</b>

<b>Interminable galleries wind across and over each other,</b> spanning fathomless pits on spindly natural bridges. Hours you walk, with no sign of relief until— light! You scramble and dig, extricating yourselves until you come to stand on a small ledge above an incredible sight: a vast necropolis, scattered with duskclad pillars and strange pyramids, cyclopean arches spanning fathomless chasms of darkness.<br/>At the center of it all, casting a shadowy pall over the city, stands a mausoleum of godly proportions. Atop the grim entrance, <b>ominous signs are carved.</b>

After some fumbling in the dark <b>the passage starts to slope upwards.</b> It is some time however before you come to a thin crack in the wall. You tear eagerly at the crevice, feeling it crumble easily under your hands. As you slip out an ominous rumble echoes through the passage as it collapses behind you. <b>Trapped!</b> Before you, the quietly frothing waters of a hidden fountain, kept from all human eyes for millenia, welcome you. Perhaps this is what the legends truly meant— life in the most improbable of places? You fade slowly...</b><br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>The ascent is steeper than you had anticipated,</b> and the sheer drop inreasingly intimidating. You stare down at the waters and a strange faintness comes into your heart. Breath deserts you, trembling seizes your limbs. The rocks surrounding the basin, far, far below, seem jagged and cruel, and you could almost thear them calling to you, yearning for a taste of your flesh, of your marrow.<br/>Some time later you find yourself struggling back down the cliffside. When you have drunk from the waters, you feel tired, and <b>decide it probably best if you rejoin the rest of the expedition.</b>

<b>You turn regretfully from the shimmering waters</b> and journey back to reconvene with the rest of the expedition.They feel none of your disappointment in not having found the Lost Necropolis, and it does not marr their enthusiasm in hearing of the wonders and beauties of your journey, however fruitless it may have been.

<b>The task is more arduous than it seems.</b> After much befuddlement you manage to find a point of convergence somewhere in the distant desert hinterlands. Gathering supplies, you hastily head into the desert, braving the scorching heat and dismally chilly nights in your quest for long-lost reward.<br/>As you head further into the dunes however, you are swiftly sobered by the realization that you may already be hopelessly and irretrievably lost, for <b>how to tell one dune from another in an endless sea of sand?</b>

<b>No hope but to trust the instinct of the king of the desert.</b> Hopefully the camel will know the way to some nearby oasis. If not...<br/>As soon as the beast's bridle is unlatched it darts across the sand, vanishing beyond cresting dunes at a steady amble while you rush to follow.<br/>Fortune favours you! After some running and considerable cursing, you come to the bustling oasis of Awis, a waterspring tucked at a crossroads of dark crimson mountains. Legend claims the waters hide a gateway the Lands of the Dead. <b>Perhaps hope is not entirely forlorn yet!</b> It would only take a short climb, then a long, steep dive...

<b>The land is harsh and unforgiving.</b> There is little shade to be found during the day, when the searing rays of the sun glare down disapprovingly on you. What shade there is turns out not to be safe. Exhausted, you fall asleep under an overhanging rock, only to wake at a sharp pain in your neck— two telltale puncture holes. The young historian is nowhere to be found. You wonder if the Lord of Sands will have mercy on you— it seems unlikely— He is not known for being merciful.<br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>The venom of an asp has taken you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>The desert sky at night has a soothing, calming quality.</b> Though the stars are strange and foreign, and many familiar constellations are disconcertingly twisted, you chart a rough cartography of the skies to correspond to the desert before you.<br/>It is just a few days before you come again to the desert's edge, into lands where thirst can easily by quenched and rest had for a nominal fee, yet <b>it will be with no small pride</b> that you will recount your strange experience among the dunes to the rest of the expedition.

<b>The stars are strange and contrary.</b> Familiar landmarks of the heavens seem oddly missing, as you scan the night for anything sympathetic. Something does not wish you to find a way out of the desert. You steel forward to the best of your ability, charting vague patterns and routes across increasingly desiccated paper, but every passing day drives you closer to death and insanity. Perhaps a cautionary tale will be told of your and the young archaeologists' disappearance.<br/><br/>You wake up. Pale and dizzy beneath a great ceiling fan in a sweltering hotel room. <b>It seems it was a bout of Cholera that took you to the edge and back again.</b>

<b>Her scepticism shows plainly on her face.</b> Grave robbers are found often in these lands, and doubtless she counts you among their number. You press her for support, arguing your good faith, but it only serves to distress her further. She holds the precious map to her tightly, fear in her eyes, and bolts into a nearby array of drapes, calling for help as she disappears amid the colourful weaves.<br/>Before you can protest you innocence, <b>several burly, sour-faced guards gather around you threateningly.</b>

<b>The guards blanch.</b> 'A grave robber, her? But she is one of the scholars studying at the House of Sands! If she is selling our heritage...' The guard pales at the implications, then streaks off into the streets furiously after the young woman.

<b>Fortunately you sighted the House of Sands as you passed it by</b>. You thread a swift way through the crowd towards it's sun-dressed pinnacles, hoping the guards will be delayed enough for you to get there first.<br/>As you round a narrow alley onto the ornate steps leading to the entrance hall you see the young scholar heading inside with a troubled look on her face.<br/> Pulling her aside to a discrete alcove despite her protestations, you urgently explain that rogues masquerading as guards are after her!

<b>The city is a sprawling metropolis, and the House Of Sands could be anywhere.</b> You try cobbling together information from broken conversations and fragments of your journey up to here, but to no avail.<br/>You are dismayed to find that you have traced paths back to the harbour where your ship berths— and where a mighty company of guards awaits. Despite your crew's protests they drag you off in chains, and it is abundantly clear despite the language impediment that they have no intention to release for months.<b>If the expedition is to continue, it will be beset by a heavy delay.</b>

<b>The guards burst into scornful laughter.</b> 'A respected scholar, a thief? You would need to be a better liar than even the sly jackal to make anyone believe that, stranger.' With a shimmer of death, blades are drawn. 'There is but one punishment for those who attempt to steal our history from under us.' It is then from nowhere, that your captain appears, "this individual..." he eyes you wearily, "is under the protection of Her Majesty the Queen. She will ensure they are brought to trial." Eventually the local guard relent and turn heel, convinced either by Captain or by your crew—lurking in the shadows, swords at the ready— it matters not. <b>You doubt your little excursion will go down well back aboard ship.</b>

Whatever unfortunate fate awaits the young researcher, you cannot help but feel it will be her just <i>deserts.</i> Had she accepted your offer, you might both be spying the golden pillars of the Necropolis by now...<br/>Best not to dwell on it; doubtless once the guard has questioned her, he will come looking for you. <b>Better for all if they find you long gone.</b>

The guards are still eyeing you suspiciously when <b>you loose fire from the hip</b>, drawing pistols and stealing rifles from the fallen. As bystanders scream and run for cover, you make out the figure of the young scholar moving towards a side-alley. You bring rifle to elbow and fire one clean, precise warning shot over her shoulder.<br/><b>She freezes, then turns with slow reluctance to face you.</b>

<b>'Hardly much of a choice, is it?' She scowls angrily at you.</b> 'Very well, but know that I will rather die than see a thief lay hands on the Statue.'<br/>Barely trying to hide her distaste at you and your crew, she leads you swiftly away from the chaos into a low house where she lays a ragged, age-tarnished map over a three-legged table. Strange symbols abound all over it, etched over crisscrossing lines all leading up to a city facing a jackal's head.<br/>'Assiout, as mentioned in the Book of the Dead. And here: "Follow the Opener-of-Paths, Anubis <custom-entity tag="jackal_128px_dark"/>, the divine embalmer, who holds the key to Assiout." <b>We need but find where the trail begins!'</b>

Eyes blazing with hatred, <b>she hands you the map</b> before bolting off down the alley. Not bothering to follow, you quickly repair to a discreet tea-house some way off and examine your prize. The map is ragged and age-tarnished, but readable. Strange symbols abound all over it, etched over crisscrossing lines all leading up to a city facing a jackal's head.<br />A note, tied to the parchment with dry reeds, states <i>Assiout, as mentioned in the Book of the Dead. And here: "Follow the Opener-of-Paths, Anubis </i><custom-entity tag="jackal_128px_dark"/><i>, the divine embalmer, who holds the key to Assiout." </i><b>Cryptic, certainly, but not completely unintelligible.</b>

<b>Time is against you</b> and you have little time to exact more from her before inquiries about the shooting trace their way back to your ship.<br/> Keeping your head stooped and your hat brim low you thread a circuitous route back to the harbour upon the delta and <b>order sails be let loose immediately.</b>

<b>A flash of searing pain</b> crumples you to the swirling ochre dust before you can even react. As your senses fade, you hear bystanders scatter fearfully as the guards fire a few celebratory shots into the air. It is much later that you hear, very softly, the familiar voice of the captain. "This individual..." you sense he is eyeing you wearily, "is under the protection of Her Majesty the Queen. She will ensure they are brought to trial." You drift back to sleep and awake two days later to find yourself back at sea, and your wounds treated. <b>From the lukewarm reception, you sense your little excursion has not gone down well with the expedition.</b>

<b>No map is worth dying for.</b> Crestfallen, you find yourself clapped in irons and dragged to a cell in a ledge tower of a citadel wall, some miles off from the city. When the sentence of several weeks is made known to you, you can take comfort only in the knowledge that only a few weeks of watery slop and bedding down in your own filth stands between you and <b>being allowed to return to your ship.

<b>"Well it has been lovely meeting you, good day,"</b> you say, before finding a corner from which to follow her. Noting that your foreign garb will certainly attract a great deal of attention, you nab a big hat and try to blend in to the living extravaganza that is the city. The deceit works wonders, and all manner of sellers, merchants and grifters brush past you like a nobody. The historian leads you to a sprawling complex of pillared halls: the great library of the House of Sands!<br/>You wait for her near a heavily ornamented pilaster then <b>strongarm her into a nearby empty alley as she passes by.</b>

<b>Your attempts at discretion are hampered by your general ineptitude.</b> It is not long before she observes you following her, and leads you through a tortuous maze of blind passages, right into the hands of a troop of guards! Before you can react, she whispers something to them under her breath then darts off into a side-alley while <b>some of the soldiers draw weapons and advance towards you.</b>

<b>A grey feeling settles upon you as you give the order to unfurl and heave.</b> Rigging cracks taut and sails fill to bursting with crisp winds, yet even the fresh breeze of the tide can do little to wash away the ambient morosity. You turn restlessly back, gazing at the distant shorelines, to what you can still see beyond, tantalisingly out of reach: the promise of the adventure of a lifetime.
You are now on board of your ship. Where do you want to go next?

<b>Wide, sun-touched lands stretch out before you,</b> long pale grass glittering with the night’s rain while a scattering of trees provides occasional shade from the already warm orange sun.<br/>Unseen in the dense matted grass, multitudinous creatures and creature wake to the dawning day, nattering away gaily as the savanna comes to life.<br/><b>A low dell not a mile away hides a blossoming waterhole,</b> where numerous strange and foreign beasts are certainly gathering before the day’s heat settles, but some of your crew insist that you make instead for the set of <b>monolithic rocky spurs looming high above the plains</b> some way inland – surely the view there must be worthy of a king!

<b>The climb is arduous and long,</b> but your topmen are skilled enough that they trace a forgeable path for lesser able sailors, using thick ropes and residues of flour hastily brought over from the camp.<br/>At last you reach the topmost spur, a long salient slab of ochre red stone worn by countless rainfalls and storms.<br/>Before you stretch endless wildlands, dust-coloured and windswept. In the distance, swirling rainclouds gather over a patch of darkness, and a deep golden hush lies on the land, broken only by the slow ambling of strange, tall-collared distant animals.<br/>A low threatening growl suddenly echoes behind you, and you turn to face a small pride of lions, territorially baring their fangs at your crew, and it is only to evident that <b>you have trespassed upon pride land.</b>

<b>One gunman shoulders his rifle</b> and takes careful aim at one particularly large male while the rest of your crew strive to stay as motionless as possible, hoping not to incite the beasts into action.<br/>The shot echoes deafeningly against the reared surrounding boulders and sends a threatening ripple over the lands below.<br/>Cowed by the roar of the rifle and the sight of their pridemate slumping lifeless to the ground, <b>the other lions slowly back away before turning tail</b> and disappearing into the rocks overhead, where their lair doubtless lies.

Whether owing to precipitousness or shoddy marksmanship, <b> the shot misses the powerfully built creature by several feet </b>, whistling through another lion’s tousled man before trailing away. <br/> Panicked, the would be hunter fumbles with the rifle’s lock, but an ominous crack signals the weapon’s reluctance to be used any further. <br/>The lions take a slow step towards your huddled crew, hunger and wrath in their glare. <br/><b>‘Someone hold them back!’ cries a sailor </b> before inching towards the first stone in the long series of climbs back to the plains.

<b>Two colossi, nicknamed Ajax and Hercules by your ship’s erudite skipper, step forward,</b> flexing their impressively muscular arms and slowly lashing thick stripes of leather over their clenched fists.<br/>One of them roars a challenge to the assembled felines, startling them into taking a few steps back into the shadow of the overhanging spurbr>The rest of your crew jump upon the occasion and swiftly start the long descent away from the pride’s rock.<br/>As the last of your men slip over the ledge, a low, feral snarl is suddenly heard some distance overhead: looking up, your heart sinks as you observe a host of lions emerge from various crevices and hidden alcoves around Ajax and Hercules – a pride of such size that there is certainly nothing even a hundred men might do to fend them off.<br/>A sudden burst of raucous, bawdy song bursts from over the ledge in Ajax’s barytone, and the second later you see Hercules jump to meet you, <b>urging all of you to run away as swiftly as possible.</b>

<b>Two burly southerners, thick-necked and ruddy, step forward hesitantly</b> while the rest of your crew slip as discreetly as possible over the ledge onto the path back to the savanna.<br/>There is a long-minute’s hushed, precipitous silence before you hear whispers of quiet, nervous conversation up above followed by an ear-shattering shriek.<br/>You turn to see one of the two men topple over the ledge, plummeting to the distant grassland, while the other barrels into the train of your crew, scattering them in a desperate attempt to flee.<br/>The descent immediately turns into a rout, harried by cruel claws and sharp fangs, and <b>many a sailor is seen for the last time pulled into a thick bush by a powerful paw.</b>

<b>Years of well-trained service are easily forgotten in the face of mortal peril.</b> Sailors push and pull each other to be first to descend onto the lower ledges, away from the increasingly threatening felines.<br/>One sour-faced woman, stops an aged sailor along her way, roughly shoving him towards the delighted lions. He stumbles and falls with a sickening crack onto the stone, blood soon clotting his hair and pooling on the dark red rock.<br/>The smell of blood infuriates the lions, and what last reservations they had are forgotten – pouncing upon the stragglers, they swiftly rend them to pieces, and <b>the cries of the wounded and dying, abandoned to their grisly fate, follows you long after the pride rock has disappeared in the distance.</b>

<b>The captain knows he must do what is right</b> – do the lives of the many not outweight the lives of the few, and are sturdy, aged hands not valued more in a storm that those of youngling?<br/>Yet the lad’s wan, stricken face haunts him long after the garbled, bloodied crying of the cabin boy, horrifyingly close despite the distance, is silenced by a merciful beast, and <b>none of your crew know untroubled sleep for many a week.</b>

Acting as one, <b>your crew start stamping the ground rhythmically,</b> battering the stone with such force that it trembles while fiercely waving their arms in large circles, concealing their terror as best they can.<br/>Startled, <b>the lions slowly edge backwards,</b> their low growls no longer threatening but worried, <b>and promptly disband,</b> gracefully bounding up into the chetive prickly bushes where their den must be hidden.<br/>

<b>Dry wood and kindle abound</b> despite recent rainfalls, so that a series of short pyres are built around the lair’s entrance. One sailor strikes a flint and tinder lighter, and soon bright flames cast the rock’s deep shadows far back into the cave.<br/>Rain-soaked grass and leaves are then thrown onto the fires, spurting voluminous columns of creamy grey smoke.<br/>There is a moment’s bated silence as the fumes invade the lair, before <b>a powerful shape leaps through the haze – only to be caught by a score of sailors lying in wait</b>, and deftly tied and subdued.<br/>The lion roars its fury and anguish, to no avail, and your crew swiftly return to camp, triumphantly bragging about their prize.

<b>Finding kindle dry enough to start a fire proves difficult</b> atop the pride’s rock, especially with recent rains. You struggle to light small piles of damp grass and twigs, but your efforts only attract the newly emboldened lions’ attention – one female leaps onto a sailor struggling with a tinder box, roaring defensively.<br/>The man leaps backward, narrowly avoiding a killing blow. Blood spurts to the ground as a ghastly tear appears in his jaw, and his teeth can be seen through the wound. Not wishing to risk further injury, your crew take cover behind what small, flickering torches they have managed to light and start the <b>achingly slow descent back to the plains, carrying their gored companion.</b>

Preferring to err on the side of safety, <b>your captain orders a swift retreat down the spur</b>, while the pride is cowed and cautious.<br/>Evening finds you all huddled around the campfire, exaggeratedly recounting the encounter with the pride to those sailors who had stayed behind.<br/>A sudden cry of wild dogs is heard distantly in the night, and <b>you wonder at the beauty and majesty of this foreign land, strangely satisfied with the bloodlessness of your expedition.</b>

<b>The pride is undeterred by your efforts to shout and stomp them away</b>. Ignoring the increasingly high-pitched cries sallying from your crew, they prowl up to the edge of the overhanging slab, preparing to pounce. You look around at your crew, but the expedition up the spur seemed so harmless that none of them brought a rifle along - save one lean and dark-faced young woman, who carries a strange, narrow-barreled firearm by her side. <b>A new, overseas pistol model</b>, certainly, and <b>not one you entirely feel comfortable resting your odds of survival upon</b>. Perhaps cornering the lions when they land to subdue them might be easier, or repelling them with a hail of rocks?

<b>You swiftly order a loosening of the ranks – if the beasts pounce, they should immediately be surrounded.</b> The order comes not a moment too soon: one particularly impatient and impressive male leaps into the fray. You prepare to corner and subdue it when <b>a powerful fist crashes into the side of the beast’s head mid-leap,</b> sending it sprawling to the ground several feet away, dazed.<br/>Their initial surprise overcome at the strength and precision of Ajax, a usually surly but powerfully muscular gunman, your crew hastily retreat off the spur while the lion is stunned and its companions cowed.<br/>Tales abound around the campfire that night of the mighty feat of ‘Ajax, he of the One Punch’, but <b>they cannot entirely make up for the crew’s sensation that they only narrowly escaped with their life.</b>

<b>One of the lions pounces upon a young man in the front ranks.</b> He ducks, hoping to avoid the beast and corner it, but sharp claws rake into his shoulder, blood spurting on the surrounding sailors as the lad crashes under the creature’s weight. His companions pummel the lion with their fists, but it barely seems to acknowledge the blows, and busies itself with goring the unfortunate lad. A lioness follows suite, leaping at a mate’s steward and opening his throat with vicious teeth, and all pretense of resistance finally abandons your crew: <b>broken, the sailors disband and flee back to the savannah,</b> routed and haunted by the dreadful fates of their comrades.

<b>Her face breaks into a dark grin and she draws the pistol to her hip with lightning speed.</b> Sunlight glares off the gleaming silvery metal and a series of rapid-fire shots flare from the muzzle with deadly precision and speed.<br />There is a moment's unbelieving, bated silence as four lions crumble to the dusty ground, blood oozing from the small round wounds in their forehead.<br />The woman smiles satisfactorily before returning her pistol to its holster with consumate ease, then a roar of admirative cheering and whooping rises from your crew, pushing the already distressed surviving lions back into their lair.<br />As you make you way down from the spur, sailors crowd around the sharpshooter to listen to her description of her pistol - the last six-shooter from C. industries, robust and reliable, and already <b>the legend of the woman who drew faster than her own shadow spreads like wildfire.</b>

Grinning darkly, she draws the weapon with lightning speed, keen to show off her skill. Precipitation makes for poor marksmanship, however, and only one of the six rapid-fire shots hits its target. The lion roars, its mane matted by swift flowing blood, while its companions furiously pounce on the young woman. Powerful jaws close with a sickening crack on her skull, bursting it open in a splatter of gore which sends surounding sailors reeling and vomiting.<br />A famished growl is heard from above before a newly woken group of slavering beasts jumps into the fray, rending with teeth and claw as your crew run for their lives.<br />When the survivors finally reach the safety of the camp, the count of the dead tallies over a score, and the scent of blood and death hangd heavy in the savanna air, so that no sleep is to be found amid the host of preying, watchful eyes in the dark.

<b>You stoop hurriedly to grab a series of sharp rocks,</b> pelting them towards the approaching creatures. They back away unhurriedly, clearly weathering the storm before return to their hunt. Some of them issue low growls when an errant rock strikes their flanks, but <b>most of them seem unworried by the attempt – if, perhaps, slightly discountenanced.</b>

Some of your crew weep to see carefully cured meats and fresh-salted fish tossed to the beasts, but <b>all agree that they would rather lose food that become food.</b><br/>The offering pacifies the pride long enough for your sailors to swiftly head back down the spur – <b>a terrifying encounter certainly, but one that is sure to reward them with many an admiring drink in the taverns of the Old World.</b>

<b>You had expected to be back to camp by noon, and consequently brought very little food along – hardly enough to placate the hungering lions.</b> Perhaps it is merely your imagination, but a low rumbling runs through the dark rock as the beasts edge threateningly closer, and you feel unseen eyes avidly observing you.

<b>Your crew stealthily edge through the high grass towards the hidden waterhole.</b> As they reach a ledge where the soft soil has fallen into the muddy waters below, you gasp in wonder at the teeming life gathered here. Scores of creatures huddle at the edge of the water – tall-necked spotted giraffes spread their legs awkwardly to lean down to the surface while nervous meerkats and contemptuous gnus eye the waters warily (possibly not without reason, as you spot several suspiciously mobile logs not far from the banks).<br/>Something trumpets loudly somewhere off to your left, and a herd of elephants thunders through the undergrowth, clearing a wide berth as they tread into the murk-swirling water.<br/>Suddenly the ground starts to shake violently – <b>you wheel to see a manifestly infuriated rhinoceros charging your company!</b>

Your crew scatter as <b>one tall woman, made lean by years of working in the rigging, steps up out of the grass to face the charging beast</b>. She straightens proudly, defiance flashing in her eyes, and waits for the inevitable blow.<br/>At the last instant, she steps gracefully aside, sending the beast hurtling into the thick tree behind her. <b>Stunned by the impact, the rhinoceros staggers slightly,</b> shaking its head to extricate its horn from the torn flesh of the tree.

<b>Several sailors nimbly tie the creature’s legs together,</b> carefully avoiding its trashing head. Sensing the binding, the rhinoceros rears, kicking out violently, but your men tug on the ropes and the beast comes crashing down on its side, fuming but motionless.<br/><b>It takes considerable effort to drag it back to camp, but the dumbfounded look on the rest of the crew’s face is worth every bead of sweat.</b>

By the time ropes are brought out to secure it, <b>the rhinoceros has struggled free of the tree</b> and rounds furiously on the oncoming sailors. They attempt as best they can to bind its legs, dancing dangerously in and out of a flurry of rearing and kicking, but the massive creature proves impossible to subdue, and it is not long before <b>it barrels out of the encirclement, thundering away into the savanna to your crew’s disappointment.</b>

A horde of gnus stampede past your crew, evidently alarmed by the thunderous attack of the rhinoceros, separating you from the beast.<br/>Leaping upon the opportunity to escape the maddened creature and its threatening bulk, <b>you promptly retreat back to camp, thrilled by your escape</b> and the impressively dramatic skills of the woman who deceived the rhinoceros.

Your captain singles out a sailor renowned for his talent in deftly manoeuvering the rigging in the heaviest storms and orders him to lure the beast into a nearby tree.<br/><b>The man stands nervously,</b> his terror evident as the rhinoceros obliques right into his path. <b>He tries to lurch aside at the last minute, only to be skewered by the beast’s impressive nasal horn</b> in a splatter of blood and broken bone splinters.<br/>A terrified roar rises from the nearby waterhole as the gathered animals sense the gore and panic, their anxiety soon turning into a stampede! <b>Those crew members that do escape the terror-stricken beasts are found wandering restlessly at night,</b> longing for some unseen and solitary company, a haunted and bloody shadow in their eyes.

<b>Years of seamanship has made your crew adept at swiftly climbing</b> the rigging of a moving, storm-tossed ship, so that scaling the low, tortuous trees hardly proves a challenge.<br/>The rhinoceros tromps to a halt when it realizes its quarry has vanished, looking around with dull, rage-shot eyes before retreating into the sun-worn high grass.<br/>As the sailors ease down from their hiding places, they dejectedly realise that the creature’s tonitruous charge has chased all the animals from the waterhole, and <b>there is naught left to do but to retreat back to camp.</b>

<b>All scramble for low branches and scalable knots in the thick, tortuous trunks of the surrounding trees.</b> Most find easy purchase and disappear into the dense foliage in a matter of seconds.<br/>A few sailors, however, head for a young silver-barked tree, supple and tall but clearly unable to bear the weight of all three. They tussle, pushing each other away while reaching for a low branch as the rumble of the rhinoceros’s charge grows nearer.<br/>The third man attempts to hoist himself up, but his companions roughly push him back, shouting that the branch won’t stand the weight of all three – before seeing the stranded sailor trampled underfoot by the beasts, abundant blood pooling on the ground amid scattered bone and flesh.<br/><b>Satisfied that it has repelled the attackers, the monster leaves after conscientiously trampling the body in full sight of every crew member,</b> a scene which will surely haunt all of them until their dying day.

<b>It is well known among naturalists that rhinoceri have limited vision,</b> and the information is immediately doled out to your crew in hurried whispers. Taking great care to avoid sudden movement, all sailors step out of the creature’s immediate path and take up resolute stillness.<br/>The beast grinds to a halt when it realises its foes have suddenly vanished. It tosses and turns its voluminous head, eyeing the high undergrowth for any sign of movement or hostility.<br/><b>After a long, breathless moment of indecision, it finally turns away and tromps down to the waterhole, to take long slow draughts of water.</b>

<b>Your attempts to convince the sailors to stay motionless would have been more efficient had four thousand pounds of armoured, horn-touting, furious beast not been hurtling towards them.</b> One lad, seeing the beast drawing ever nearer, gives in to fear and breaks into a mad escape.<br/>The rhinoceros immediately turns towards him, and <b>your crew seize the opportunity to retreat, unsuccessfully trying to ignore the fact the young man would certainly be spurred or trampled by the beast while they made their escape.</b>
'Where to -  it is charging!'

<b>Attempts to outrun the rhinoceros are futile.</b> Turning the stragglers, it singles out a limping fellow and bellows before charging him and skewering him with its horn.<br/>As the body of their crewmate is tossed and broken underfoot, <b>your sailors flee back to camp, haunted by visions of a dark bloodied horn piercing through the man’s abdomen in a spurt of gore.</b>

<b>Rhinoceri are swift, but their bulk makes for poor mobility;</b> your crew dance in and out of the beast’s vision, confusing it considerably as it dizzily turns from one evanescent figure to the next. As soon as it is sufficiently dazed, <b>your men dart behind the creature’s colossal backside and run hurriedly back to camp,</b> concealing themselves in the tall grass, fearing at every instant to hear a furious bellow just behind them and see the beast’s grey armour loom out of the shrubbery to run them down.

<b>You swiftly order a loosening of the ranks – if the beasts pounce, they should immediately be surrounded.</b> The order comes not a moment too soon: one particularly impatient and impressive male leaps into the fray. You prepare to corner and subdue it when <b>a powerful fist crashes into the side of the beast’s head mid-leap,</b> sending it sprawling to the ground several feet away, dazed.<br/>Their initial surprise overcome at the strength and precision of Ajax, a usually surly but powerfully muscular gunman, your crew hastily retreat off the spur while the lion is stunned and its companions cowed.<br/>Tales abound around the campfire that night of the mighty feat of ‘Ajax, he of the One Punch’, but <b>they cannot entirely make up for the crew’s sensation that they only narrowly escaped with their life.</b>

<b>One of the lions pounces upon a young man in the front ranks.</b> He ducks, hoping to avoid the beast and corner it, but sharp claws rake into his shoulder, blood spurting on the surrounding sailors as the lad crashes under the creature’s weight. His companions pummel the lion with their fists, but it barely seems to acknowledge the blows, and busies itself with goring the unfortunate lad. A lioness follows suite, leaping at a mate’s steward and opening his throat with vicious teeth, and all pretense of resistance finally abandons your crew: <b>broken, the sailors disband and flee back to the savannah,</b> routed and haunted by the dreadful fates of their comrades.

Guns are nervously loaded and trained on the creatures, when <b>a sudden burst of rapid-fire shots sallies from the rear ranks of your crew.</b> Three of the lions stumble before falling over the brink to your feet, heads bloodied by uncannily precise sharpshooting.<br/><b>The remaining lions back away in terror while your crew wisely head back down the spur,</b> gushing over the young shooter’s skills yet unpleasantly aware of how narrowly they have just avoided death.

<b>Your crew fumble to load their weapons,</b> and a volley of haphazard shorts crackles through the warm air. In their precipitation, however, the marksman failed to aim properly and <b>their shots miss the beasts by several feet.</b><br/>Enraged, the lions pounce upon the foremost sailors, ripping and goring them with powerful maws, their blood spattering through the air onto the rest of your horrified sailors. Abandoning all pretense of bravery, <b>your entire crew flee the towering rocks, followed by the dying cries of their comrades.</b>
